Effective Date
Compensation
May 1, 2017 $200.00 for each Board of Trustees or Committee of the Whole meeting attended, with a maximum of $600.00 per
month.
The amount shall be paid monthly in accordance with the Village's usual and customary payroll practices.
(Ord. 2016-44, 10-24-2016)
D. Compensation Increases: Beginning on May 1, 2010, and every May 1 thereafter, the compensation of the Village President/Liquor Control
Commissioner, the Village Clerk and the Village Trustees shall be increased by the lesser of three percent (3%) or the percentage increase
in the Consumer Price Index for the twelve (12) month period preceding May 1. The term "Consumer Price Index" shall mean the Chicago
area Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers for all items as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States
Department of Labor or any successor index created by the Department of Labor as a substitute index that measures the average change in
prices of goods and services purchased by urban consumers. The most recent consumer price index available on May 1 of each year shall
be used in applying this subsection to any increases in compensation. If the index is a negative number, then there shall be no decrease in
the compensation, but the compensation shall remain the same as the previous fiscal year. Amounts for monthly and per meeting
compensation shall be rounded to the nearest whole dollar.
E. Payment Of Compensation: Compensation shall be paid monthly, in arrears, on the first payroll of each month. (Ord. 2006-36, 8-14-2006;
amd. Ord. 2012-44, 11-12-2012)
1-8-4: INDEMNIFICATION:
A. It is found and declared by the village president and board of trustees ("village") as follows:
1. The village has the power to indemnify its officials, both elected and appointed, pursuant to law. (Ord. 92-78, 11-23-1992)
2. The term "officials", as used in this section, shall mean the president and trustees, the village administrator, department directors and
appointed committee and commission members, as well as all other officers of the village, whether or not currently serving. (Ord. 92-78,
11-23-1992; amd. 2012 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 29/548
3. It is in the best interest of the village to provide for the indemnification of its officials, both elected and appointed, against claims, expenses
and liabilities to which such persons may be subject by reason of their having acted in their capacity as a public official.
B. The village shall indemnify any official who was or is a party, or may become a party, to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or
proceeding, whether civil, administrative or investigative, by reason of any act or omission, error, misstatement or misleading statement, or
neglect or breach of duty or any other action which could reasonably be construed to have been committed, attempted or allegedly
committed or attempted by such person in the discharge of his or her duties in his or her capacity as an official, both elected and appointed,
against expenses (including attorney fees), judgments and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her in
connection with such action, suit or proceeding, if such person acted in good faith in a manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in
the best interests of the village. This indemnification shall not apply to any claim, suit, action or proceeding:
1. Which is for the return by any such official, both elected and appointed, of any remuneration paid in fact to him or her without the previous
approval of the village if it shall be determined by judgment or other final adjudication that such remuneration is in violation of law or if
such remuneration is to be repaid to the village under a settlement agreement.
2. Which is for an accounting of profits made from a purchase or sale by such official, both elected and appointed, of village property for any
transaction prohibited by the village ethics ordinance1.
3. Which is brought about or contributed to by the fraudulent or dishonest acts of such official, both elected and appointed, if a judgment or
other final adjudication adverse to such official establishes that acts of active and deliberate dishonesty were committed or attempted by
such official with actual dishonest purpose and intent and were material to the cause of action so adjudicated.
4. Which is brought about or contributed to by any criminal activities of such official, and there has been a judicial determination of said
criminal activities.
5. For which the village is not authorized by law to provide indemnification to the official, either elected or appointed.
6. With reference to any of the aforementioned enumerated items, a presumption shall exist that indemnification shall apply unless a judicial
finding to the contrary is made.
C. The termination of any action, suit or proceeding, contrary to the best interests of the official, by judgment, order, settlement or other
resolution shall not create a presumption that the official did not act in good faith in a manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in
the best interests of the village. To the extent that an official has been successful, on the merits or otherwise, in the defense of any action,
suit or proceeding or in the defense of any claim which qualifies herein for indemnification, such person shall be indemnified against
expenses (including attorney fees) actually and reasonably incurred by such person in connection therewith. However, the village shall not
withhold payment of attorney fees until the conclusion of any legal proceedings, but shall pay the attorney fees of the official on a timely
basis.
D. The village shall indemnify only those officials, either elected or appointed, from whom or with respect to whom the village has received
written notice of a claim. To the extent practicable, any notice from such official shall be mailed as soon as practicable and shall identify the
official seeking the indemnification and contain information with respect to the time, place and circumstances of the claim, the names and
addresses of any injured persons or other claimants and the names of any available witnesses. In the case where legal proceedings have
been commenced, indemnification may be denied if the official fails to mail to the village, within twenty (20) days after receiving service of
process, a copy of such process relating to a claimed wrongful act unless: 1) the village has otherwise received a copy of, or written notice
of, such process; or 2) the failure to notify within such twenty (20) day period does not adversely impact upon the village's ability to defend
against such claim. Notice of the claim shall be made in writing to the village clerk.
E. The village shall indemnify the official for any damages, expenses, court costs and legal fees incurred in connection with any defense of or
settlement of a claim, action or proceeding where such settlement has been approved in advance by the village, or where the village refuses
or fails to approve such settlement, such settlement is deemed to be reasonable by independent legal counsel chosen by both the village
and the official.
F. Any indemnification pursuant to this section shall be made by the village upon a determination that indemnification of the person is required
by this section. Such determination shall be made: 1) by the president and board of trustees by a majority vote of a quorum of the board who
were not parties to such claim, suit, action or proceeding; or 2) if such quorum is not obtainable or, even if obtainable, where a majority of a
quorum of the board fails to approve the indemnification, by independent legal counsel chosen by both the claimant and the village board.
G. Any official against whom any action, suit or proceeding is brought may employ his or her own attorney; provided, that such attorney is
reasonably acceptable to the village; and provided further, that the costs of such attorney shall not be paid by the village unless the village
attorney or independent counsel for the village shall have advised the village that such official's interests should not be represented by the
same counsel that represents the village in such action, suit or proceeding.
H. The indemnification provided herein shall be in addition to and not exclusive of any other indemnity or insurance or other protection to which
the indemnitee may be entitled. The indemnification provided herein shall be payable whether or not the village has obtained insurance
therefor and, in the case of the death of the indemnitee, shall inure to the benefit of his or her heirs or successors. (Ord. 92-78, 11-23-1992)
1-8-5: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT POLICY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 30/548
All persons shall have the right to be free from discrimination on the basis of race, color, creed, national ancestry and sex in hiring and
promotion practices of any employer.
(Ord. 77-58, 11-28-1977; amd. 2012 Code)
The village hereby recognizes that the absence of overt discrimination does not in itself assure equal opportunity to women and minority groups,
and that other factors such as poverty, inferior education, and traditional recruitment or employment practices also hinder the minority applicant.
The affirmative action program, with its result oriented procedures and specified goals, is intended to combat those handicaps. Furthermore,
through the efforts of the village administrator, there will be a continuing process of review of the hiring practices, the administrative procedures
and the promotion structure of the village. (Ord. 77-58, 11-28-1977)
1-8-6: PARTICIPATION IN ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT FUND:
The village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois municipal retirement fund, effective January 1, 1974. (Ord. 73-45, 9-26-1973)
ARTICLE A. FINANCE DIRECTOR-TREASURER1
1-8A-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
There is hereby created the office of finance director-treasurer. The finance director-treasurer shall be appointed by the village president, with
the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The finance director-treasurer shall have a term of office of one year and until his successor
has been chosen and has qualified. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. In addition to the duties specifically delegated to the finance director-treasurer by this code, the director of finance-treasurer shall have all
duties and powers which are assigned by any statute of the state of Illinois or any code, ordinance or resolution of the village to the office of
village treasurer and shall serve ex officio in such capacity concurrently with his full time employment as director of the finance department.
B. The finance director-treasurer shall:
1. Perform such duties as may be prescribed for the village treasurer by statute or ordinance.
2. Receive all monies paid into the village, whether directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or
employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the village president and clerk.
3. Review all claims for reimbursement against the village and submit a list of all outstanding claims to the finance, personnel and
administration committee for their consideration, together with his report as to the status of the claims.
4. Prepare and file all fiscal, financial, and tax reports, documents, and materials as may be required of the village to be presented to public
agencies of the federal, state, and county governments, and to be presented to such financial institutions as may be doing business with
the village.
5. On or before June 15 of each year, submit to the board of trustees a report of his estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary
to defray the expenses of the village during the current fiscal year. For the purpose of making this report, the finance director-treasurer
shall require all officers of the village to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their offices or departments; and any
proposed improvements and the estimated expense thereof; a statement of all unperformed contracts; and the amount of all unexpended
appropriations of the preceding year. His report shall also:
a. Classify the objects and purposes of such estimated expenditures and the amounts required for each;
b. Show the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, from all sources;
c. Show the amount of liability on which interest is to be paid;
d. Show the bonds and debts due and payable and the dates when such are due and payable; and
e. Give such other information regarding the financial situation of the village as the board of trustees may require.
6. Deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as provided by law and keep the deposit of the village
monies separate and distinct from his own monies. The finance director-treasurer shall not use village monies for personal or private use.
7. Keep such books, accounts, and records as may be required by statute or ordinance, and establish, supervise, and maintain the financial
record system of the village. The records, books, and accounts of the finance director-treasurer shall show, among other things, all monies
received by him showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012
Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 31/548
1-8A-3: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUND:
All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the finance director-treasurer as a special fund to be applied only to the
payment of the improvement, or bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was made, and
such money shall be used for no other purpose unless to reimburse the village for money expended for such improvements. Payment on bonds
or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the statutes and the law, and the finance director-treasurer shall keep his books and accounts in
such a manner so that proper prorations in payments of principal and interest can be made and ascertained. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012
Code)
1-8A-4: DRAWING WARRANTS; TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
A. All warrants drawn on the finance director-treasurer must be signed by the president and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular
fund or appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable, and no money shall be otherwise paid except as
may be provided by statute.
B. Money shall not be transferred by the finance director-treasurer from one fund to another after it has been received by him, nor appropriated
to any other purpose than that for which has been collected or paid, except as may be ordered by the president and board of trustees in
manner and form prescribed by statute. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
1-8B-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village attorney, which office shall be held by an attorney or firm of attorneys admitted to the bar and
licensed to practice law in the state. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
1-8B-2: APPOINTMENT; LEGAL ADVISOR:
The village president may appoint and retain the village attorney to act as legal advisor to the village, and said village attorney shall render
advice on all legal questions affecting the village, as the board of trustees may request from time to time. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012
Code)
1-8B-3: DUTIES:
A. Prepare Documents: The village attorney shall prepare all ordinances and resolutions required by the board of trustees, and shall draft and/or
supervise the content of any contracts, leases, or other documents and instruments to which the village may be a party.
B. Attend Meetings: The village attorney shall attend all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees and such meetings of boards and
commissions of the village or committees of the board of trustees as he shall be directed by the board of trustees. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
C. Suits And Actions: The village attorney shall defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in
which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the village, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of
the village. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8B-4: COMPENSATION:
For such services, the village attorney shall be paid such salary and compensation as shall be agreed upon by the village attorney and the
board of trustees at the time of appointment. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
1-8C-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor, who shall be an attorney licensed to practice in the state. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971)
1-8C-2: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 32/548
The village prosecutor shall be appointed by the village president and shall prosecute all matters involving the violation of any ordinances of the
village or in which the village may be interested. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8C-3: ASSISTED BY VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The village attorney shall assist the village prosecutor at the request of the board of trustees. The village prosecutor shall notify the village
attorney of any notice of appeal served in connection with the imposition of any fine or other penalty for a violation of a village ordinance. The
village prosecutor shall report to the village attorney on the progress of any matters which have been continued from time to time and their final
disposition. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971)
1-8C-4: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the village prosecutor shall be as determined by the village board of trustees. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
1-8D-1: TITLE:
This article shall be entitled AN ORDINANCE CREATING AND ESTABLISHING THE OFFICE OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR IN AND FOR
THE VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-2: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
A. There is hereby created the office of village administrator. The village administrator shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, for such term as determined at the time of his or her appointment or by contract or as otherwise provided
by law. The village administrator shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with special reference
to his or her actual experience in, and knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of his or her employment as set forth herein.
At the time of such appointment, the village administrator need not be a resident of the village, but shall reside either within the village or
within reasonable distance therefrom during the term of office.
B. Upon the appointment of the village administrator, the president shall issue a certificate of appointment, under the corporate seal, to the
village clerk. The village administrator shall be commissioned by warrant, under the corporate seal, signed by the village clerk and the
president. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village administrator shall take and subscribe the oath as set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-10-25, as may be amended from time to time. This oath, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 89-40,
9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8D-4: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation and benefits as the president and board of trustees shall determine by ordinance, or
alternatively, pursuant to any contract which defines said terms. No compensation shall be paid to the village administrator in addition to that
provided in the ordinance or by the terms of any contract; except, however, the village administrator shall be entitled to reimbursement for any
reasonable actual expenses incurred by him in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8D-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village administrator shall be the administrative director of all departments of the village. He shall be responsible to the president and board
of trustees for the proper administration of all affairs of the village. The village administrator shall perform such duties in addition to those which
may be prescribed by law, and shall be subject to such other rules and regulations as the president and board of trustees may provide by
ordinance from time to time. Specifically, but without limitation, the village administrator shall have the following powers and duties: (Ord. 89-40,
9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
A. Supervise and coordinate the work of all departments of the village now in existence or that may hereafter be created by the president and
board of trustees, except as limited or restricted by any ordinance of the village; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 33/548
B. Recommend to the president and board of trustees in regard to the hiring of all employees of the village. He shall recommend to the
president the removal or suspension of any department director or employee when such removal or suspension shall be consistent with the
village personnel manual and/or any relevant provisions of the Illinois state statutes. All such recommendations for the hiring of employees
shall be based upon merit and qualifications. Any recommendation for either hiring or removal shall be made without regard to political belief
or affiliation;
C. Review annually, salaries, wages and hours and conditions of employment of all department directors and employees under his jurisdiction.
No expenditure shall be made on account of or pursuant to such appointment or employment by the village administrator unless authorized
by or under the applicable appropriation or budget of the village, and all such expenditures shall be subject to the approval of the president
and board of trustees; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
D. Act as purchasing agent of the village and make or supervise all necessary purchases of equipment, materials and supplies by the village,
and all contracts therefor. The village administrator shall have the power to enter into contracts for services and purchase goods and
materials involving up to and including twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) without the prior approval of the village board, as long as those
services, goods and materials have been previously appropriated. Contracts and purchases in excess of this amount shall require the prior
approval of the village board, whether or not they have been previously appropriated. The village administrator may issue rules and
regulations governing requisitions and the transaction of business of purchasing between himself, as purchasing agent, and the department
directors and employees of the village; (Ord. 2011-35, 9-12-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
E. Make recommendations concerning compensation for each department director and employed position in the service of the village, including
minimum, intermediate and maximum rates; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
F. Recommend the creation, consolidation and combination of offices, positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive
departments of the village;
G. Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government of the village and services maintained by the
public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed; (Ord. 89-40, 9-
25-1989)
H. Prepare and present to the president for his consideration at the end of each fiscal year an estimate of income and expenses for the ensuing
year; prepare the annual appropriation ordinance and tax levy ordinance in the form and within the time required by law; and prepare the
annual budget; and submit such ordinances and budget to the president for his submittal to the board of trustees, together with the village
administrator's opinion and recommendations covering their important features; and upon the adoption of such ordinances and budget, the
administration of the same. To the end that all financial matters of the village are coordinated, the village finance director-treasurer is hereby
directed to cooperate with the village administrator and to assist him in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by this article;
I. Act as business manager for the village under the direction of the president and board of trustees and in cooperation with the village finance
director-treasurer and clerk; control and direct all expenditures made by the village; supervise the keeping of all necessary records and
books of accounts of the village that are not under the supervision of the finance director-treasurer or clerk, by ordinance or statute; (Ord.
89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
J. Attend all regular and special meetings of the village board, and committees thereof, unless excused by the same;
K. Render or cause to be rendered monthly to the president and board of trustees written statements showing the exact financial condition of
the village as of the end of the preceding month, including the statement of current assets and liabilities, and a summarized statement of
receipts and expenditures;
L. Make recommendations to the president and board of trustees, or appropriate committee thereof, relative to the adoption of such ordinances
and resolutions as he may deem necessary or expedient; meet with the standing committees of the president and board of trustees as often
as necessary and when requested;
M. Make special reports or recommendations to the board of trustees, or the appropriate committee thereof, as the board of trustees may
request; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
N. Render to all department directors of the village and said department directors shall render to him all such assistance as is possible in the
performance of their respective duties, and all department directors and employees of the village shall furnish and disclose to the village
administrator such oral or written information and material relating to the affairs of the village as he shall request;
O. Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the village and the location of such property; be responsible for the care and
custody of all village property which is not by law assigned to some other department director or body for care and control; (Ord. 89-40, 9-
25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 34/548
P. Devote his entire time during reasonable hours to the discharge of his official duties. He shall hold no other employment for compensation;
except, that he may receive occasional stipends for consultation with others not connected with the village, making speeches, writing
professional articles, and the like; provided, that such secondary duties do not conflict with his duties as village administrator; and
Q. Perform such other duties as may be required of him by the corporate authorities not inconsistent with the statutes of the state of Illinois or
with the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-6: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The village administrator shall abide by the relevant provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes pertaining to conflicts of interest, disclosures of
economic interests and contracts, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-
101 et seq., and as the same and any other relevant provisions of the state statutes may be amended from time to time by the Illinois general
assembly. The village administrator shall promptly disclose any potential conflict of interest to the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 89-40,
9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8D-7: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The village administrator may be removed by the president on any formal charge whenever the president is of the opinion that the interests of
the village demand removal. Such removal is subject to the payment of any valid remaining portion of his contract, if hired by contract. The
president shall report the reasons for such removal to the village board at a meeting to be held not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days
after the removal. If the president fails or refuses to report to the board of trustees the reasons for the removal, or if the village board, by a twothirds
(2/3) vote of all its members authorized by law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the village administrator, thereupon, shall be
restored to office. Upon restoration, the village administrator shall give a new bond and take a new oath of office. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-8: ACTING VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
In the event the village administrator shall be incapacitated from performing the duties of his position, a qualified person shall be appointed as
acting village administrator by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, during such absence or incapacity, with all the
powers and duties of that office, who shall perform all the duties thereof without furnishing any additional bond if such appointee shall already be
under bond to the village in any other capacity. If such appointment shall be a person not already under bond to the village, such appointee shall
furnish a bond in such amount and with such surety as may be approved by the president and board of trustees. The compensation to be paid
the acting village administrator shall be fixed by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE ENGINEER
1-8E-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM; RESIDENCY:
A. The Village Engineer shall be appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, for such term as determined
at the time of his appointment; however, such term of office shall expire no later than the end of the term of the appointing President and as
soon after as his respective successor is appointed and has qualified. At the time of such appointment, the Village Engineer need not be a
resident of the Village, but shall reside either within the Village or within a reasonable distance therefrom during the term of office.
B. Upon the appointment of the Village Engineer, the President shall issue a certificate of appointment, under the Corporate Seal, to the Village
Clerk. The Village Engineer shall be commissioned by warrant, under the Corporate Seal, signed by the Village Clerk and the President.
(Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Village Engineer shall take and subscribe the oath as set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/3.1-10-25, as may be amended from time to time. This oath, so subscribed, shall be filed in the Office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-
1989; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-3: COMPENSATION:
The Village Engineer shall receive such compensation as the President and Board of Trustees shall determine by ordinance. No compensation
shall be paid to the Village Engineer in addition to that provided in the ordinance; except, however, the Village Engineer shall be entitled to
reimbursement for any reasonable actual expenses incurred by him in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code;
Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 35/548
A. The Village Engineer shall be generally responsible to the Corporate Authorities in the performance of his statutory powers, duties and
services, but he shall be primarily responsible to and subject to the supervision, direction and control of the Village Administrator. He shall be
required to attend regular and special meetings of the Village Board, Committee of the Whole meetings and conferences as and when
requested by the Village President, the Board of Trustees and/or the Village Administrator.
B. The Village Engineer shall perform such duties, in addition to those which may be prescribed by law, and shall be subject to such other rules
and regulations as the President and Board of Trustees may provide by ordinance from time to time. Specifically, but without limitation, the
Village Engineer shall have the following duties: (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1. Advise the Village President, Village Board of Trustees, and Planning and Zoning Commission on all matters concerning the engineering
and construction of public works within the Village; (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2014-48, 10-27-2014; Ord. 2017-42,
11-13-2017)
2. Review and approve or disapprove all engineering for all subdivisions and public improvements within the corporate limits of the Village
and, to the extent permitted by State law or Village ordinance, for a distance of one and one-half (11/2) miles outside the corporate limits of
the Village;
3. Inspect and approve or disapprove the construction of all public works within the corporate limits of the Village and, to the extent permitted
by State law or Village ordinance, for a distance of one and one-half (11/2) miles outside the corporate limits of the Village;
4. Prepare all engineering plans and specifications for and the supervision of all construction of all public improvements proposed to be
constructed by the Village; provided, that the President and Board of Trustees may, in any instance where they deem it appropriate, retain
an independent engineer to prepare such engineering plans and specifications and supervise such construction. In the event an
independent engineer is retained as aforesaid, the Village Engineer shall be responsible for the supervision of such independent engineer
and shall periodically report to the President and Board of Trustees with respect to the performance of such independent engineer;
5. Prepare all long range planning and forecasts of public improvements. The Village Engineer shall periodically advise the President, Board
of Trustees and the Village Administrator with respect thereto;
6. Maintain complete and accurate records of all public improvements in the Village and establish standards for subdivision improvements as
required by the subdivision ordinance of the Village; and
7. Perform such other duties as may be delegated to him by the ordinances of the Village or assigned to him by the President, the Board of
Trustees and/or the Village Administrator. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-5: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The Village Engineer shall abide by the relevant provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes pertaining to conflicts of interest, disclosure of
economic interests and contracts, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-
101 et seq., and as the same and any other relevant provisions of the State Statutes may be amended from time to time by the Illinois General
Assembly. The Village Engineer shall promptly disclose any potential conflict of interest to the Village Administrator. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989;
amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-6: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The Village Engineer may be removed by the President, on any formal charge, whenever the President is of the opinion that the interests of the
Village demand removal. The President shall report the reasons for such removal to the Village Board at a meeting to be held not less than five
(5) nor more than ten (10) days after the removal. If the President fails or refuses to report to the Board of Trustees the reasons for the removal,
or if the Village Board, by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all members authorized by law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the Village
Engineer, thereupon, shall be restored to office. Upon restoration, the Village Engineer shall give a new bond and take a new oath of office.
(Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)

VILLAGE DEPARTMENTS
