LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person
appointed guardian or given custody under the juvenile court act.
MINOR: Any unemancipated person over seven (7) years of age but not yet twenty one (21) years of age.
NEGLIGENTLY: A person acts "negligently" when he fails to be aware of a substantial and unjustifiable risk that circumstances exist or that a
result will follow and where such failure constitutes a substantial deviation from the standard of care which a reasonable person would
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 102/548
exercise in the situation.
PARENTS: Includes the father and mother of a minor child, whether by birth or adoption, or shall be deemed the parent having legal custody
of the minor in the event the parents are divorced or separated. The "parent", as used in this section, also shall be deemed to mean "legal
guardian".
RECKLESSLY: A person acts "recklessly" when he consciously disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that circumstances exist or
that a result will follow and where such disregard constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of care which a reasonable person would
exercise in the situation. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003; amd. 2012 Code)
B. Responsibility For Minors:
1. No parent shall give or deliver alcoholic liquor to his or her minor child for the minor's consumption unless the consumption of alcoholic
liquor by such minor is in the performance of a religious service or ceremony under the direction, supervision and approval of the parent of
such minor in the privacy of a home or established religious building.
2. No parent shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or negligently give or deliver alcoholic liquor to, or permit the possession of alcoholic
liquor by, his or her minor child, or any other person under the age of twenty one (21), unless such minor or person under the age of
twenty one (21) is making a delivery of such alcoholic liquor pursuant to order of his parent, in pursuance of his employment or otherwise
as allowed by subsection B1 of this section.
3. No parent shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or negligently give, deliver, invite or permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor by any
minor on or about any premises owned, leased or controlled by such parent except as otherwise allowed by subsection B1 of this section.
4. Parents shall restrain or prevent their minor children from consuming alcoholic liquor where the parent knows or, in the exercise of
ordinary care, should know of a substantial probability that his or her minor child is consuming or will consume alcoholic liquor under
circumstances which would violate the provisions of this section, the Illinois liquor control act, or any other ordinances or statutes.
5. Parents who know, or in the exercise of ordinary care should know, of a substantial probability that their minor child has consumed, is
consuming or will consume alcoholic liquor in violation of this section, the Illinois liquor control act, or any other ordinances, statutes or
amendments thereto shall restrain or prevent their minor child from operating or driving a motor vehicle on the public streets and ways of
the village in violation of any ordinance, law or statute.
6. Parents who know, or in the exercise of ordinary care should know, of a substantial probability that their minor child has consumed or will
consume alcoholic liquor in violation of this section, the Illinois liquor control act, or any other ordinances, statutes or amendments thereto
shall restrain or prevent their minor child from committing acts which constitute vandalism, theft, disorderly conduct, the unjustifiable use of
force, or the violation of any ordinance, law or statute. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
4-2-23: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
A. Disorderly Conduct And Violations Of Law:
1. All licensees hereunder shall have the affirmative duty of reporting to the on duty radio dispatcher of the Bloomingdale police department
any and all incidents of disorderly conduct or any and all criminal violations or violations of this chapter which take place within or upon
premises for which a liquor license has been issued pursuant to this chapter immediately upon observance or notification of the incident.
The licensee, employee or agent making a report of an incident shall identify himself or herself to the police dispatcher and state the
nature of the incident.
2. For purposes of this chapter, "disorderly conduct", as used herein, shall mean such act or behavior of any person which, in any
unreasonable manner, alarms or disturbs another or provokes a breach of the peace within or upon such premises. Failure to report to the
police, as herein provided, shall be deemed sufficient cause to suspend or revoke the license issued hereunder. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-
2003)
B. Gambling And Violations Of Law: It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit, or to fail to prevent when reasonably apparent, any "gambling",
as defined in state law, or any other violations of state law or ordinances of the village occurring in or upon the licensed premises, except for
video gaming as provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 2014-11, 2-24-2014)
C. Nude Dancing And Sexually Provocative Conduct: The following kinds of conduct on premises in the village licensed to sell alcoholic liquor
are prohibited:
1. The performance of acts, or simulated acts, of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, or flagellation or any
sexual acts which are prohibited by law.
2. The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals.
3. The actual or simulated displaying of the pubic hair, anus, vulva, genitals, or female breasts below the top of the areola.
4. The permitting by a licensee of any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes to public view any portion of his or
her genitals, anus, pubic hair or female breasts below the top of areola.
5. The performance of topless and/or bottomless dancing, go-go dancing, stripping, lingerie or bathing suit fashion shows, or similar
entertainment where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on activities or anatomical areas described in
subsections C1, C2 and C3 of this section.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 103/548
6. The displaying of films or pictures depicting acts, a live performance of which is prohibited by the regulations stated in this subsection.
D. Telephone Sales And Deliveries: The retail sale of alcoholic liquor ordered by telephone, facsimile or other similar method to be delivered,
mailed or shipped to the purchaser or any other party is prohibited except for licensees holding a license which specifically allows for
telephone sales and deliveries under certain conditions. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
4-2-24: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
A. The local liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to enter and empowered to authorize a law enforcement or health officer to enter
at any time upon any building or premises licensed hereunder, except for residential or dwelling portions of such buildings, to determine
whether or not the provisions of the Illinois liquor control act and this chapter and any rules or regulations promulgated by the local liquor
control commissioner are being complied with, as authorized by 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-4 and 5/10-8 et seq., and all such entry
and actions shall conform to the above stated statutory requirements and any subsequent amendments thereto.
B. It shall be unlawful to refuse to grant the admittance to the premises for which any license has been issued, at any time, upon verbal request
of the liquor control commissioner or any police officer or health officer authorized by him, of the village, for the purpose of determining
whether or not the Illinois liquor control act or the provisions of this chapter are being violated, including section 4-2-22 of this chapter, by
way of periodic liquor compliance checks, pursuant to the powers granted by subsection A of this section and by 235 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/10-8 et seq. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
4-2-25: EXAMINATION OF BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The local liquor control commissioner shall have the right to examine or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a local license or
for a renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served as provided by statute, and to examine or
cause to be examined the books and records of any such applicant or licensee; to hear testimony and take proof for his information in the
performance of his duties; and for such purpose, to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of the state. For the purpose of
obtaining any of the information desired by the local liquor control commissioner under this section, he may authorize his agent to act on his
behalf, as provided by statute. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
4-2-26: RECORDS AND NOTICES:
The village clerk shall keep a complete record of all retail liquor dealers' licenses issued and shall furnish copies thereof to the police
department, village administrator and the board of trustees. Upon revocation or suspension of any license, the village clerk shall immediately
give written notice thereof to the police department, village administrator and the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
4-2-27: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE; FINES; APPEALS:
A. Revocation Or Suspension Authorized: The local liquor control commissioner may suspend or revoke any liquor dealer's license for any
violation of any provisions of this chapter or for any violation of any state or federal law pertaining to alcoholic liquor, as provided and in the
manner provided by statute.
B. Fines: In addition to the suspension, the local liquor control commissioner may levy a fine on the licensee for such violations. The fine
imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month period, one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or
subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. Not
more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines under this section may be imposed against any licensee during the period of his
license. Proceeds from such fines shall be paid into the general corporate fund.
C. Notice Of Hearings: Notice of hearings regarding such suspension or revocation shall be sent to the police department, village administrator,
and the president and board of trustees.
D. Compliance With Statute: The citations of violations, notice of hearings, conduct of hearings and decisions thereon shall be as provided by
statute at 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-9.
E. Appeals: The appeal of any decision of the local liquor control commissioner shall be limited to a review of the official record of proceedings
of such local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 2009-35, 9-29-2009)
4-2-28: RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSEE FOR EMPLOYEE ACTIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the actions or inactions of any employee, agent or representative of a licensee shall be directly imputed to the
licensee, who shall be directly responsible for such actions or inactions. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 104/548
4-2-29: INSTRUCTIONAL PROGRAM FOR PERSONNEL; ATTENDANCE REQUIRED:
A. The completion of a state certified beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training (BASSET) program is required for all persons
who sell or serve alcoholic beverages, all management personnel working on the premises and anyone whose job description entails the
checking of identification for the purchase of alcoholic beverages, pursuant to that license. (Ord. 2013-32, 10-14-2013)
B. A "state certified BASSET training program" shall be defined as a BASSET program licensed by the state of Illinois liquor control commission
(ILCC) as required by 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-12(11.1) and 5/6-27 and title 77 of the Illinois administrative code, chapter XVI, part
3500. All licensed BASSET providers shall be required to have on file all licenses and certificates to prove current qualifications and provide
a certificate of course completion and a card (a picture type identification is optional) to participants as proof of completion.
C. Any new owner, employee, or agent requiring BASSET training shall, within ninety (90) days from the beginning of their employment with the
licensee, complete an ILCC BASSET approved seller/server training program and shall, until completion of the BASSET program, work
under the supervision of a person who has completed BASSET training.
D. Any new manager who has not completed classroom ILCC BASSET seller/server training within the prior twelve (12) months shall complete
BASSET seller/server training from the Bloomingdale police department at the first available training session, not to exceed ninety (90) days
from the beginning of their employment with the licensee and shall, until completion of the BASSET program, work under the supervision of
a person who has completed BASSET training. (Ord. 2013-11, 2-11-2013; amd. Ord. 2013-32, 10-14-2013)
E. A photocopy of the certificate of completion for all owners, managers, employees, or agents required by this section to have BASSET training
shall be maintained by the establishment in a manner that will allow inspection, upon demand, by any designee of both the state or local
liquor control authorities.
F. The village and establishments must honor all state of Illinois liquor control commission (ILCC) BASSET approved programs.
G. Failure of an owner, manager, or employee to attend a BASSET training program, when specifically required by the local liquor control
commissioner, shall constitute a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003; amd. Ord. 2013-32, 10-14-2013)
4-2-30: PENALTY:
In addition to any other sanctions and remedies provided by statute, any person, firm or corporation who shall be convicted of violating any
provisions of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 2003-40, 10-27-2003; amd. 2012
Code)
Chapter 3
AMUSEMENT DEVICES
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine, game, table or other device designed, intended, displayed or kept as an amusement game or test of skill
and for the playing of which a charge is made. The term amusement device, when used in this chapter, shall include, but not be limited to,
devices commonly known as pinball machines, shuffleboards, bowling machines and coin operated games of skill but shall not include
regulation bowling alleys or pool or billiard tables. Amusement devices shall include any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug,
token, plate or disk, or the use of which is made available for any valuable consideration, may be operated by the public generally for use as a
game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. The term shall include such devices as marble machines, electronic
games, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations, or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be
indicated.
ATTENDANT: Any person acting for and in behalf of an operator or game room licensee.
GAME ROOM: Any premises in which three (3) or more amusement devices are operated for commercial purposes.
GAME ROOM LICENSEE: Any person, firm, corporation or association in immediate control of premises, including any owner or lessee thereof,
within or upon which three (3) or more amusement devices are operated for commercial purposes.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association engaged in the business of distributing, placing, leasing or selling
amusement devices, as defined in this section, with an agreement to maintain, service or supply such amusement devices to any premises
located within the village where such amusement devices are operated for commercial purposes. The term "commercial purposes", wherever
appearing within this chapter, shall have its generally understood meaning and shall include, without limitation, an intent to operate amusement
devices for gain or profit.
PERSON: Shall include the following: any person, firm or corporation or association which owns or leases any amusement device; the person,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 105/548
firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such device is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation or
association having control over such device. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. Ord. 98-13, 4-13-1998; 2012 Code)
4-3-2: AMUSEMENT DEVICE TAX:
A. An annual tax for each calendar year is hereby imposed upon all amusement devices operated for commercial purposes within the village.
The amount of said tax is one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per device for first ten (10) devices, and seventy five dollars ($75.00) per
machine for each amusement device in excess of ten (10) located on the licensed premises payable annually. (Ord. 2014-50, 11-10-2014)
B. The amusement device tax shall be paid by the owner of such device to the village finance director-treasurer. The village finance directortreasurer
shall issue, as evidence of the payment of the tax, a self-voiding adhesive tax emblem to be placed on each device. Such emblem
shall bear the words "Village of Bloomingdale - Amusement Device Tax" and such other wording as may be prescribed by the finance
director-treasurer. It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate said tax emblem during the year for which it was issued. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-
1993; amd. 2012 Code)
C. It shall be unlawful for the owner or lessee of any premises or person in control of such premises to permit the installation or use of
amusement devices within the village for commercial purposes unless the tax has been paid and is evidenced by a tax emblem affixed to the
amusement device. Each such device shall be plainly labeled with the name, address and telephone number of its owner. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-
1993)
4-3-3: OPERATOR'S LICENSE:
A. License Required: No one shall engage in the business of being an operator of amusement devices without having first obtained a license
therefor.
B. Application For License: An application for an amusement device operator's license shall be made in conformance with the general business
application requirements of this code1.
C. License Fee: The license fee for an amusement device operator's license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each license year and
shall not be prorated. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
D. Investigation Of Applicant; Approval Or Denial: The application for an amusement device operator's license shall be referred to the chief of
police for investigation and verification of the facts stated therein and the business methods of the operator. Unless the chief of police shall
find that the operator has been convicted of a felony, or that he has violated any law or ordinance imposing any tax, or if either the owner or
operator has employed illegal measures to promote the use of his amusement devices, or that the place where said amusement device is to
be used is not qualified under the provisions of this chapter, he shall return the application to the finance director-treasurer with his approval;
otherwise, he shall return it with a statement of his reasons for refusing to approve the application. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. 2012 Code)
E. Operators That Are Game Rooms: Where the operator is also a game room licensee, the operator shall, in each instance, apply for a game
room license and shall not be required to also apply for an operator's license unless such applicant is an operator for a game room other
than one for which he is the licensee. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-4: GAME ROOMS:
A. License Required; Fees: No one shall operate a "game room", as defined in section 4-3-1 of this chapter, without having first obtained a
license therefor. The license fee for a "game room" shall be as provided in section 4-1-5-1 of this title and shall not be prorated. The game
room license fee shall be paid by the licensee to the finance director-treasurer. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. 2012 Code)
B. Special Use Permit Required: No person shall receive a license pursuant to this chapter authorizing the operation of a "game room", as
defined in section 4-3-1 of this chapter, unless a special use permit has first been issued permitting the operation of a game room pursuant
to the terms and conditions of the zoning ordinances of the village. No special use permit shall be granted for the operation of a game room
and no license shall issue, except as an accessory use to a principal use of the premises for which the license and special use are sought. A
"principal use" is herein defined to mean any of the permitted or special uses, other than a game room, set forth under the village zoning
ordinance. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
C. Game Rooms In Shopping Malls:
1. The provisions of subsection B of this section notwithstanding, a game room in an enclosed shopping mall of at least one million
(1,000,000) square feet may be the principal use of the premises.
2. In addition to the other provisions set forth in section 4-3-7 of this chapter pertaining to duties of licensees, the following provisions shall
apply to game rooms located in enclosed shopping malls of at least one million (1,000,000) square feet:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 106/548
a. Two (2) or more attendants/employees must be on duty at all times overseeing the operation - one at each end of the store. Attendants
must be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
b. The licensee is responsible for any costs associated with police calls for service and added mall security personnel needed because of
problems overflowing from the store into a common area or parking lot, as well as problems within the store itself.
c. The licensee shall restrict the wearing of gang colors, articles of clothes, signing and other forms of gang activity within the store.
d. No liquor may be consumed or sold within the facility licensed.
e. The village reserves the right to review terms and conditions of the lease to ensure that provisions relating to security are adequate.
f. All amusement devices must be properly licensed by the village and all fees paid before the game room facility may open for business.
g. The village retains the right to precondition a game room license upon adequate numbers and quality of security personnel.
h. Ingress and egress to a game room in an enclosed shopping mall with at least one million (1,000,000) square feet shall only be
available from the interior of the enclosed mall and not through the exterior of the enclosed mall. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. 2012
Code)
D. Ineligibility For License: No license shall be issued hereunder if the applicant, or if a partnership or corporation, any officer, director, or
shareholder owning five percent (5%) or more of the shares of said corporation, or any member of the partnership, or any manager or agent
in charge of the premises has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving dishonesty or false statement.
E. Application For License:
1. Each application for a game room license shall contain the following information:
a. The name, address and phone number of the applicant.
b. Location of place of business.
c. Principal kind of business engaged in by applicant.
d. Statement of whether business will be conducted by a manager or agent, and the name, address and phone number of any such
manager or agent.
e. A diagram showing the number of amusement devices to be located on the premises, the location of each device on the premises, and
a description of each device.
f. If a corporation, set forth the following:
(1) Corporate name and address.
(2) Date and place of incorporation.
(3) Names and addresses of corporate officers and directors.
(4) Names and addresses of all persons or legal entities owning five percent (5%) or more of the corporation's stock.
g. If a partnership, set forth the following:
(1) Date and place when the partnership was formed.
(2) The names of all general partners.
(3) If a limited partnership, the names of all limited partners owning five percent (5%) or more interest in the partnership.
h. State whether any individual, partner, officer, or shareholder has ever been convicted of any criminal offense in any state or federal
court or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge; if yes, state the offense.
i. If the business on the subject premises will be conducted by a manager or agent, state whether the manager or agent has ever been
convicted of any criminal offense in any state or federal court or has ever forfeited an appearance bond on a felony charge; if yes, state
the offense.
2. Applications for license shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the chief of police and the other copy to be referred to
the village administrator.
3. There is an application processing fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), due and payable at the time the application for license is
submitted to the village.
F. Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance Or Denial Of License: The application shall be investigated by the chief of police and village
administrator in accordance with the provisions of section 4-1-6 of this title. The village administrator shall thereupon issue the license to the
applicant. If it is determined that the applicant does not qualify for a license, the applicant shall have the right of appeal pursuant to section
4-1-17 of this title.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 107/548
G. Number Of Licenses: There shall be no more than seven (7) game room licenses, in the aggregate, issued and outstanding at any one time.
(Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
H. Location: No game room shall be located within five hundred feet (500') of any place of worship or school. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. 2012
Code)
I. Floor Area Required Per Device: There shall be a maximum of one amusement device for each forty (40) square feet of floor area on the
premises, exclusive of aisles and exit areas. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-5: DISCLOSURE STATEMENT:
Whenever any trustee of a trust or any beneficiary or beneficiaries of a trust make application for a license pursuant to the terms of this chapter,
such application shall identify each beneficiary of such trust, giving the respective names and addresses of each and their respective interest or
proportionate share of ownership. All such disclosure statements shall be filed and maintained for public inspection in the office of the village
clerk. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-6: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSES:
A license issued hereunder shall not be transferable from person to person or place to place and shall be usable only at the place and by the
person designated in the license. The word "person", referred to herein, shall mean any natural person as well as partnership, corporation, firm
or association. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-7: DUTIES OF LICENSEES:
A. Gambling Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to permit gambling on the premises. Any licensee or attendant who observes any gambling on the
premises, or has reasonable grounds to suspect that gambling is taking place, shall immediately cause the removal from the premises of
such persons as are involved in the gambling activity.
B. Attendant Required: The licensee or an attendant shall be on the premises at all times in which the business is open to the public and shall
be in such a position as to have a clear view of all the amusement devices and activity taking place on the premises.
C. Noise And Disturbances:
1. It shall be unlawful for the licensee hereunder to permit such noise, either by mechanical means or noise on the part of the patrons, which
shall cause a disturbance to the adjacent and surrounding uses as would cause the normal operation of said businesses to be damaged
or unreasonably disturbed.
2. All licensees or attendants hereunder shall have the affirmative duty to report to the police department any and all incidents of a
"disturbance of the peace", as defined and regulated in this code2, which takes place within the licensed premises or outside the premises
within one hundred feet (100') from the entrance, whether personally observed or upon observation or notification. Failure to report to the
police as herein provided shall be deemed sufficient cause to revoke the license issued hereunder.
D. Clean, Sanitary Premises: The licensee shall cause the premises to remain in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and shall place such
waste receptacles in and around the premises so as to accomplish the above.
E. Parking; Unobstructed Sidewalks: A licensee shall provide adequate and orderly parking for all bicycles and motor vehicles and shall keep
the storefront unobstructed so that the sidewalks are clear and open to pedestrian traffic.
F. Persons Under Influence Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any licensee or attendant to knowingly permit any individual under the influence of
alcohol or drugs on the premises where amusement devices are in use. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-8: GAMBLING DEVICES PROHIBITED:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or permit the operation of any "gambling devices", as
defined in section 28-2 of the Illinois criminal code. Any such gambling device shall be seized by the police in accordance with section 28-5 of
the Illinois criminal code. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-9: INSPECTIONS:
Each licensee shall permit inspection of any licensed premises during regular business hours by village officials to determine compliance with
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 108/548
the provisions of this code. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993)
4-3-10: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
Every license issued under this chapter is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, of suspension or revocation of the same
should the licensee, directly or indirectly, permit the operation of any amusement device or game room contrary to the provisions of this chapter,
the ordinances of the village, or the laws of the state of Illinois. In addition, a license may be suspended or revoked for any of the grounds set
forth in section 4-1-16 of this title. The procedures for suspending and/or revoking any such license shall be in accordance with those provided
in section 4-1-16 of this title. Any revocation of the authorization or licenses issued in pursuance of the provisions of this chapter shall ipso facto
bar reinstatement of the same, or the granting of a new license, to any corporation, partnership, or individual shareholder, partner, or owner of
which was a shareholder, partner, or owner or a licensee whose license has heretofore been revoked, for a term of not less than one year
immediately following such revocation. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd. 2012 Code)
4-3-11: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be liable for a penalty in the amount of one hundred
percent (100%) of any unpaid fee and, in addition, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 93-43, 8-9-1993; amd.
2012 Code)
4-3-12: APPLICATION TO EXISTING BUSINESSES:
This chapter shall not be construed to extend to or affect any activity for which a permit or license was issued or application for permit or license
filed prior to the effective date hereof, except for fees not yet due or payable. (Ord. 98-13, 4-13-1998)
Chapter 4
RAFFLES
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
AUXILIARY OR AFFILIATES: Shall include an auxiliary or affiliate of a licensee.
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who have joined together to advance the commercial, financial,
industrial and civic interests of a community.
CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those
eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
EDUCATIONAL: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by
methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented
in tax supported schools.
FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members
and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of government by caring for those that otherwise would
be cared for by the government.
LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit
and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other
reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not for profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a
result of the operation.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery, as defined in section 28-2(b) of the criminal code of 19611, conducted by an organization licensed under this chapter,
in which:
A. The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of
numbers or by some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance; and
B. The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of
acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery; except, that the winning chance shall not be determined by the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 109/548
outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest.
RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship.
VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses,
widows, or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the
general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; AUTHORITY TO ISSUE; JURISDICTION:
A. License And Compliance Required: No person, firm or corporation shall conduct a raffle without first having obtained a license pursuant to
this chapter. Each raffle must be authorized by a separate license, except as authorized by subsection 4-4-6B of this chapter, and must be
conducted in accordance with the applicable provisions of this chapter.
B. Authority To Issue Licenses: The village clerk or his/her designee (herein referred to as "village clerk") shall have the authority to issue
licenses for raffles subject to the limitations set forth in subsection 4-4-3A of this chapter.
C. Jurisdiction: A license issued by the village shall authorize the sale of raffle chances only within the borders of the village. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-
26-2004)
4-4-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE; INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
A. Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide nonprofit, religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal, educational or veterans organizations that
operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5) years immediately before
making application for a license and which have had, during that entire five (5) year period, a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out
their objectives, or to a nonprofit fundraising organization that the licensing authority determines is organized for the sole purpose of
providing financial assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness,
disability, accident or disaster, or to political committees in accordance with the requirements set forth in 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes
15/8.1.
B. No raffle license shall be issued to:
1. Any person who has been convicted of a felony.
2. Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling promoter.
3. Any person who is not of good moral character.
4. Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or B3 of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest,
or in which such person is active or employed.
5. Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2, or B3 of this section is an officer, director, or employee, whether
compensated or not.
6. Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or B3 of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
"raffle" as defined in section 4-4-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
A. Application for a license shall be made in writing, no fewer than thirty (30) days before the intended sale of raffle chances, on forms provided
by the village clerk. Each license and application for license shall contain the following information:
1. The name and address of the applicant;
2. The area within the village in which the raffle chances will be sold and issued;
3. The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued;
4. The date, time, manner and location(s) of determining the winning chances;
5. A sworn statement attesting to the nonprofit character of the applicant signed by its presiding officer and secretary;
6. A copy of the applicant's articles of incorporation and/or charter; and
7. Such other information as the village clerk may require.
B. The village clerk shall act on a license application within thirty (30) days from the date of application. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 110/548
4-4-5: CLASSES OF LICENSES; FEES:
A. Classes And Fees Established: The fee for each license shall be as set forth in the following schedule:
1. Class A: Where the aggregate value of all prizes awarded in any raffle does not exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), no license fee
shall be required.
2. Class B: Where the aggregate value of all prizes awarded in any raffle is greater than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), the license fee
shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
B. Waiver For Class B: The fee for a class B raffle license may be waived by an affirmative vote of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-
2004)
C. Payment And Disposition Of Fees: All fees for licenses required under this chapter shall be paid to the village clerk at the time of application
and shall be immediately turned over to the village finance director-treasurer. In the event the license for which applied is denied, the fee
shall be returned to the applicant; if the license is granted, the fee shall be deposited in the general fund or in such other fund designated by
the board of trustees. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004; amd. 2012 Code)
4-4-6: EFFECT OF LICENSE:
A. Each raffle license shall be valid for the duration of the contest as stated in the license application.
B. Each license issued under this chapter shall be valid for one raffle, or for multiple raffles as specified in the application, covering a period of
no more than one year, unless suspended or revoked for violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-7: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles in the village is subject to the following:
A. The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
B. No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
C. No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle.
D. The maximum fee which may be charged for each raffle chance sold or issued shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), except as
modified pursuant to subsection 4-4-8C of this chapter.
E. A licensee may rent premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also
licensed under this chapter.
F. Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license, and winning chances may be determined only at those
locations specified on the license.
G. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances only with the permission of a parent or
guardian. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-8: TICKETS AND PRIZES:
A. Tickets:
1. Each raffle ticket, chance or other raffle token shall state, on its face, the name and address of the licensee, the date or dates of the
drawings, and the prize or prizes to be awarded; provided, however, that this requirement shall not apply to any raffle in which prizes in
aggregate value under fifty dollars ($50.00) are awarded, or to any raffle in which raffle chances are sold only on the date of the drawing
during the event at which the drawing is to be conducted. No such ticket, chance or token shall be sold or issued more than two hundred
forty (240) days before the determination of the winning chance or chances.
2. If any raffle for which a license is issued under this chapter is canceled, or if any such raffle is not conducted on the date contained in the
application for license, the licensee shall refund all monies paid for any raffle chances issued or sold to the persons to whom such raffle
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 111/548
chances were issued or sold within forty five (45) days after the date on which the raffle was to be conducted or within forty five (45) days
after cancellation of the raffle, whichever is sooner.
B. Prizes: The maximum cash prize awarded in any raffle shall be one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); the maximum retail value of a
noncash prize awarded in any raffle shall be one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The aggregate value of all prizes awarded in any
raffle shall not exceed two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00), except as modified pursuant to subsection C of this section.
C. Exceptions To Limits: Should the applicant wish to request either a higher dollar cost for each raffle chance and/or a higher individual or total
prize value, said request shall be referred to the board of trustees for consideration of such an exception. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-9: GAMBLING PROHIBITED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize the conducting or operating of any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other
than a raffle as provided herein. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-10: RAFFLE MANAGER:
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffle manager designated by the organization. The manager
shall provide a fidelity bond in the sum of an amount determined by the village in favor of the organization conditioned upon his honesty in the
performance of his duties. Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the village not less than thirty (30) days prior to
its cancellation. The village administrator may waive this bond requirement when, due to the nature, past experience or competence of the
organization involved, the village administrator determines that such bond would be unnecessarily burdensome. The village administrator shall
give notice of such waiver to the village president and village board of trustees within five (5) days. Should the village administrator determine
that such a bond waiver should not be approved, the applicant may appeal said decision to the village board of trustees within fifteen (15) days.
(Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004; amd. 2012 Code)
4-4-11: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
A. Records Kept:
1. Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each
single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or
occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other
reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of
payment.
2. Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the department of
revenue of the state of Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The person
who accounts for gross receipts, expense and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for
other revenues of the organization.
B. Reports Required: Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report promptly after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership
and to the village clerk its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required
in this section.
C. Preservation Of Records: Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3) years, and organizations shall make available
their records relating to operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
4-4-12: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this
code. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004; amd. 2012 Code)
4-4-13: PUBLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The village clerk may publish rules and regulations consistent with this chapter or Illinois law governing the conduct of raffles licensed
hereunder. (Ord. 2004-39, 7-26-2004)
Chapter 5
VEHICLE SOLICITATION
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 112/548
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the indicated meanings unless a different meaning is clearly required by the context:
CHARITABLE: Shall mean and include the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic or fraternal,
either actual or purported.
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE SOLICITATION: Shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities, not done for charitable purposes,
by a person on streets or highways within the village: The sale of, offer or attempt to sell to persons riding in or operating motor vehicles or
seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuff or services of any kind, character or description, for any kind
of consideration whatever.
CONTRIBUTION: Shall mean and include the words alms, food, clothing, money, subscriptions, property or donations under the guise of a loan
of money or property.
INTERSECTION: The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines or, if none, the lateral boundary lines of the
roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles; and the shoulders and rights of way contiguous to the
paved surface.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company, association or joint stock association, church, religious sect, religious
denomination, society, organization or league, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, agent or other similar representative thereof.
RELIGIOUS AND RELIGION: Shall not mean and include the word "charitable" as defined in this section, but shall be given their commonly
accepted definitions.
RELIGIOUS OR CHARITABLE VEHICLE SOLICITATION: The oral or written request by a person on streets or highways within the village,
directly or indirectly, of persons operating or riding in vehicles, for money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea
or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a religious or "charitable" purpose
as those purposes are defined in this section. Religious or charitable vehicle solicitation shall also mean and include the following methods of
securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a religious or
"charitable" purpose as defined in this section. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5-2: RELIGIOUS OR CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS:
4-5-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Every person desiring to engage in "religious or charitable vehicle solicitation", as defined in section 4-5-1 of this chapter, from persons in
vehicles on public roadways located in the village is hereby required to make written application for a solicitation permit as hereinafter provided
and obtain such permit prior to engaging in vehicle solicitation within the village. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. 2012 Code)
4-5-2-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
A. Application for religious or charitable vehicle solicitation permits shall be made upon a form provided by, and shall be submitted to, the police
department, and shall include or be accompanied by the following:
1. The name, address and telephone number of the organization making the application and the name under which it intends to solicit
contributions, and if applicable, proof that the organization is engaged in a statewide fundraising activity. The soliciting organization shall
maintain names, addresses, telephone numbers and dates of birth in their files of all potential solicitors. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd.
Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
2. The name, address and telephone number of the person in charge of solicitation in the village. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
3. Such additional information which the chief of police may from time to time require to verify that persons who will solicit contributions are
eligible for a permit under this chapter. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4. The dates and times of day such solicitations are to be made and the intersections in the village wherein such solicitation shall be
conducted at a particular time and day. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
5. If applicable, a written statement of recent date by the attorney general of Illinois that the organization is in compliance with the provisions
of an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/2, as such statute may
hereafter be amended. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. 2012 Code)
6. A written statement from the internal revenue service that the organization is a tax exempt organization under the internal revenue code of
the United States, section 501(c)(3).
7. A certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in Illinois shall be provided to the village with the
application, insuring the solicitors and their organization for liability for damages of personal injury and property damage causally related to
an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. The certificate must state that it shall not be canceled during the period of solicitation
and will provide at least the following coverage:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 113/548
Personal injury $ 500,000.00 per person
1,000,000.00 per occurrence
Property damage 100,000.00
Nothing herein shall be construed to give permission to any solicitor to enter into traffic intersections for the purpose of soliciting in contravention
of any state or local ordinance prohibiting such intersection solicitation.
B. All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
C. The chief of police shall cause to be kept in the police department offices an accurate record of every application received and acted upon,
together with all other information and data pertaining thereto, and copies of all vehicle solicitation permits issued under the provisions of this
chapter.
D. Any individual agency desiring to solicit on roadways shall be:
1. If applicable, registered with the Illinois attorney general as a charitable organization pursuant to subsection A5 of this section;
2. Liable for injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting
agent.
3. Required to verify that each solicitor is sixteen (16) years of age or more and wears a high visibility vest. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5-2-3: NO PERMIT FEE REQUIRED:
No fee shall be charged for a vehicle solicitation permit for religious or charitable solicitation. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
4-5-2-4: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT:
The chief of police, or an authorized designee, within five (5) business days of filing of the application, after consideration, investigation and
review of the application and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant is not entitled to a permit,
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or if the application does not contain all of the information and documentation as required herein.
Endorsement shall be made by the chief of police, or an authorized designee, on the application of the reason for the denial of the application. If
the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this chapter, the vehicle solicitation permit shall be issued forthwith and sent by the police
department to the applicant. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5-2-5: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
A. Any religious or charitable vehicle solicitation permit issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police, or an authorized designee if the
holder of the permit or anyone soliciting under the permit is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or has made a
false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a solicitation permit under the terms of this
chapter. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police, or an authorized designee to the
holder of the permit in person, or by U.S. mail, return receipt requested, addressed to his residence address set forth in the application. The
permit shall become null and void upon the first to occur of the following: (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
1. Actual notice of revocation shall be made by the village to the individual or organization.
2. Receipt of the return receipt of the mailed notice to the individual or organization, whether or not delivered to the permit holder personally,
shall be retained by the village. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
B. The chief of police, or an authorized designee may temporarily revoke or suspend a permit if public safety issues arise, such as an injury to
the public or a violation of state law or other village ordinances, after issuance of the permit which the chief of police reasonably believes
require suspension of solicitation.
C. The village administrator shall hear appeals on the denial of an application for a vehicle solicitation permit or the permanent or temporary
revocation of a permit by the chief of police. A written appeal must be filed in the office of the village administrator within twenty one (21)
days after the date of denial of the application or revocation of the permit by the chief of police.
D. The appealing party shall submit what documentation it desires to have the village administrator consider with the written appeal, and the
village administrator shall render a written decision within fourteen (14) days of the filing of the written appeal.
E. The village administrator shall not be bound by the rules of evidence prevailing in the courts of law but shall, in ascertaining the conditions
and practices involved in the decision appealed, take into account all reliable, probative and substantial evidence produced by the appealing
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 114/548
party relating to the denial of the application or revocation of the permit. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5-2-6: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING:
It shall be unlawful to engage in religious or charitable vehicle solicitation on sidewalks, streets or highways within the village before the hour of
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and after the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5-3: IDENTIFICATION OF SOLICITOR AND PERMITTEE:
A. All persons engaged in religious or charitable vehicle solicitation are required to wear identification on the exterior of their clothing identifying
them individually by name.
B. Every person engaged in religious or charitable vehicle solicitation for the permittee shall display in a visible place upon his person
information identifying the full name of the organization for which he is soliciting. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2012-43,
11-12-2012)
4-5-4: PERSON IN CHARGE:
There must be a person in charge of the solicitation activity within the village limits who is present on site during the period of solicitation and
who has an operating cellular telephone with him at all times. The police department must be provided with the name of the person and the
cellular telephone number of that person. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
4-5-5: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any individual to solicit on any highway or street within the village without wearing highly visible clothing or garments.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to file an application for permit which contains false, misleading or untrue information.
C. Nothing contained in this chapter shall release or relieve any person from complying with any additional license requirement established by
the village.
D. No solicitor may knock on vehicles or their windows, nor obstruct or impede traffic.
E. Solicitors shall not attempt to solicit from operators of vehicles when a traffic signal is other than red or upon approach of a vehicle to a stop
sign. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004)
F. No "commercial vehicle solicitation", as defined in section 4-5-1 of this chapter, is permitted at any time within the village.
G. Religious or charitable vehicle solicitation on roadways will be permitted by the chief of police after receipt of a written application submitted
thirty (30) days prior to the day requested for such vehicle solicitation.
1. All such applications shall be filed with the police department.
2. This subsection applies to all streets and public roadways in the village.
H. Religious or charitable vehicle solicitation on roadways shall not be permitted except at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a
full stop, and at intersections listed in subsection I of this section.
I. Religious or charitable solicitation will not be allowed at any time on or adjacent to the following intersections because of safety concerns for
pedestrian and motor vehicle traffic at these locations:
Army Trail Road and Glen Ellyn Road.
Army Trail Road and Schmale Road.
Bloomingdale Road and Lake Street (U.S. Route 20).
Medinah Road and Lake Street (U.S. Route 20).
J. No solicitation shall be permitted at any time at a specific location if the roadway or the adjacent right of way is under construction or repair.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 115/548
K. All individuals conducting solicitation under authority of a permit issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter shall prominently display the
name of the organization for which they are soliciting upon their person so that it is clearly visible to the motoring public. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-
12-2012)
4-5-6: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
Any person who violates a provision of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. Any citation issued hereunder
shall specify the section of this chapter which was allegedly violated. The burden of proof for such violations is by a preponderance of the
evidence. (Ord. 2004-21, 4-12-2004; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
Chapter 5A
RESIDENTIAL SOLICITATION
4-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the meaning herein ascribed thereto:
REGISTERED SOLICITOR: Shall mean and include any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided, and
which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.
RESIDENCE: Shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for dwelling purposes by one or more persons, contained within any
type of building or structure.
SOLICITING OR SOLICITATION: A. Shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities:
1. Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services, of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; or
2. Seeking to obtain prospective customers for applications or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; or
3. Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publications; or
4. Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or
nonprofit association, organization, corporation, or project.
B. Soliciting or solicitation shall not include:
1. Any of the foregoing activities when undertaken by any person pursuant to a previous appointment or invitation from the property owner
or occupant of a residence; or
2. Canvassing or calling from house to house only for the purpose of communicating issues of general interest to the public, circulating
petitions concerning matters of public policy, taking surveys or opinion polls, campaigning for candidates for public office or public
questions, or communicating religious beliefs.
Due to the promotion of life, health and safety in residential areas, while the activities listed in subsections B1 and B2 of this definition
are generally not regulated, they are subject to the restrictions as listed in subsection 4-5A-6D of this chapter.
SOLICITOR: Any person who engages in solicitation. (Ord. 71-76, 9-8-1971; amd. Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
Every person desiring to engage in "soliciting" as herein defined, from persons in residences within the village, is hereby required to make
written application for a certificate of registration as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 71-76, 9-8-1971; amd. Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION:
A. Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the chief of police and filed with the police department. The
applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 116/548
1. Name and address of present place of residence of the applicant;
2. Age of applicant;
3. Physical description of the applicant;
4. Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association by whom the applicant is employed or represents; and the length of
time of such employment or representation;
5. A description of the product or subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage;
6. Period of time for which the certificate is applied;
7. The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this chapter, if any;
8. Whether or not certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked;
9. Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of violating the provisions of this chapter, or violating the ordinance of any other Illinois
municipality regulating soliciting within five (5) years of the date of the application;
10. Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, or
under federal law within five (5) years of the date of the application;
11. Such additional information as the chief of police may deem necessary to process the application.
B. All statements made by the applicant under the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath.
C. The chief of police shall keep an accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other information and data
pertaining thereto, and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this chapter, and of the denial of applications.
D. A certificate of registration will not be issued to any person in the following circumstances:
1. A person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state, within five (5)
years of the date of the application;
2. A person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under federal law, within five (5) years of the date of the application;
3. A person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, within five (5) years of the date of the application;
4. A person whose certificate of registration from the village has previously been revoked as herein provided, within five (5) years of the date
of the application; or
5. To a person who has ever been convicted of a sex offense as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-0.1 et seq., or any other
equivalent law of any other state. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-4: ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
A. The chief of police, within five (5) business days of filing of the application, after consideration, investigation and review of the application and
all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant is not entitled to a certificate, pursuant to the provisions of
this chapter, or if the application does not contain all of the information and documentation as required herein. Endorsement shall be made
by the chief of police, or an authorized designee, on the application of the reason for the denial of the application. If the applicant has
complied with all the provisions of this chapter, the certificate of registration shall be issued forthwith and sent by the police department to
the applicant.
B. Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation
of any of the provisions of this chapter, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the
issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this chapter.
C. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or by
certified U.S. mail addressed to applicant's address set forth in the application.
D. The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof.
E. The village administrator shall hear appeals on the denial of an application for a certificate of registration or the permanent or temporary
revocation of a certificate of registration by the chief of police. A written appeal must be filed in the office of the village administrator within
twenty one (21) days after the date of denial of the application or revocation of the certificate of registration by the chief of police.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 117/548
F. The appealing party shall submit what documentation it desires to have the village administrator consider with the written appeal, and the
village administrator shall render a written decision within fourteen (14) days of the filing of the written appeal.
G. The village administrator shall not be bound by the rules of evidence prevailing in the courts of law but shall, in ascertaining the conditions
and practices involved in the decision appealed, take into account all reliable, probative and substantial evidence produced by the appealing
party relating to the denial of the application or revocation of the certificate of registration. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-5: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
Every residential property owner or occupant of a residence desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations
pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter, shall comply with the following directions:
A. Notice of the determination by the residential property owner or occupant of a residence of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of
invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in the manner following:
A sign, no larger than is allowed by the village sign code herein, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence,
indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows:
NO SOLICITORS INVITED
B. Such sign so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the residential property owner or occupant of a
residence of the information contained thereon. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-6: LIMITATIONS ON SOLICITING:
A. Invitations By Property Owner Or Occupant: The property owner or occupant of a residence in the village shall make the determination of
whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their residence.
B. Notice: It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the village upon which a "residence" as herein defined is
located, to first examine the notice provided for in section 4-5A-5 of this chapter, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement
contained on the notice. If the notice states "Only Solicitors Registered In Bloomingdale Invited", then the solicitor not possessing a valid
certificate of registration as herein provided shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises; and if the notice states "No Solicitors
Invited", then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.
C. Requested Departure: Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully
depart from the premises when requested to do so by the property owner or occupant.
D. Dates And Times: It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the
doorbell upon or near any door, or rap or knock on any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of
the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing any audience with the occupant thereof and to "solicit", as defined in this
chapter, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. CST of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or
federal holiday, or in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of section 4-5A-5 of this chapter.
E. Identification Badges: It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to fail to wear an identification badge on his or her outer garments that is visible at
all times. Such badge shall be issued by the police department, and shall contain the name of the peddler or solicitor, and the name of the
group or organization, if any, on whose behalf the peddler or solicitor is conducting activities that are regulated under this chapter.
F. Rescission Or Cancellation Of Sale: It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in soliciting to misrepresent the right of a buyer to
rescind or cancel a sale under the provisions of applicable law.
G. Unlawful Acts: It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in soliciting to use any false plan, scheme or ruse; to cheat, deceive, or make
any fraudulent misrepresentation while acting as a solicitor in the village, whether through the company or organization or through an
employee or solicitor thereof. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
4-5A-7: FEES:
The fee for the license required by this chapter shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per solicitor for every solicitation request. (Ord. 2012-43, 11-
12-2012)
4-5A-8: PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 118/548
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
(Ord. 71-76, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2012-43, 11-12-2012)
Chapter 6
TOBACCO PRODUCTS SALES
4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
BUSINESS SELLING TOBACCO PRODUCTS: A retail establishment of any kind that is engaged in the sale of "tobacco products" as defined
herein.
SELL OR SALE: To sell or offer for sale at retail, barter, exchange, deliver or give away or cause or permit a sale at retail, barter, exchange,
delivery or giving away.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, loose
tobacco, plants or herbs intended for smoking; snuff; smokeless tobacco; or related smoking accessories.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic self-service device, which upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of
payment dispenses tobacco products. (Ord. 2012-09, 1-23-2012)
4-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. No person shall operate a business primarily selling tobacco products or selling tobacco products over the counter in conjunction with its
primary type of business without first having obtained a license for such business. Application for such license shall be made in conformity
with the requirements of this title. Such license shall be in addition to any other license required by this code.
B. No person shall operate or maintain within the village any vending machine for the sale of any tobacco products, nor sell any such tobacco
products by means of a vending machine without first having obtained a license according to the requirements of this title. Such license shall
be in addition to any other license required by this code. (Ord. 2012-09, 1-23-2012)
4-6-3: PROHIBITED SALES; SIGNS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for sale or deliver tobacco products to any person under the age of
eighteen (18) years. A seller of tobacco products must check the identification, including the bearer's date of birth and photograph, of all
persons twenty six (26) years of age, or younger, to verify that they are at least eighteen (18) years old.
B. Any person operating a business selling tobacco products, or where vending machines are located, shall post a sign informing the public of
the age restrictions provided herein in a conspicuous place upon the premises or machine. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall
state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND SMOKING ACCESSORIES TO PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED
BY LAW. WE CHECK I.D.'S OF ALL CUSTOMERS UNDER AGE 27.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, said letters to be at least one inch (1") high.
C. It shall be unlawful for any person, including a licensee, to give away free samples of tobacco products.
D. It shall be unlawful for any person, including a licensee, to sell single cigarettes ("loosies") or packs with fewer than twenty (20) cigarettes
("kiddie packs"), that are not contained within a sealed container, pack or package, as provided by the manufacturer, which container, pack
or package bears the health warning required by federal law.
E. It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to redeem a coupon for a tobacco product through the mail rather than at a face to
face exchange in a store.
F. It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to give away any gift or item to anyone in exchange for a tobacco proof of
purchase or as a part of a sale of tobacco products.
G. It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee or any manager, employee or agent of any such licensee, to sell, offer for sale at
retail, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, or to advertise or promote tobacco products on any right of way, park,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 119/548
playground or other property owned by the village, any school district, or any park district.
H. Except for a person operating a business selling tobacco products, no person shall sell cigarette paper. No person shall sell cigarette paper
from a vending machine.
I. No person shall sell tobacco products from a vending machine that also sells nontobacco products, with the exception of matches, unless
such vending machine is located in one of the following places:
1. Places to which minors under eighteen (18) years of age are not permitted access;
2. Places where alcoholic beverages are sold and consumed on the premises and vending machine operation is under the direct supervision
of the owner or manager; and
3. Places where the vending machine is locked and can only be operated by the owner or an employee over eighteen (18) years of age,
either directly or through a remote control device if the device is accessible to all customers. (Ord. 2012-09, 1-23-2012)
