a. Each occupant, owner or customer of any premises in the village shall provide, and at all times properly maintain, a sufficient size
and/or number of containers for that customer's garbage or refuse.
b. It shall be unlawful for any occupant, owner, or customer of any premises to deposit solid waste into a container provided for another
premises, with or without the approval of the occupant/owner/customer of said premises.
c. No garbage and refuse may be stored or placed in an interior area accessible to the public or in any exterior location other than in a
container.
d. No occupant, owner, or customer shall be limited to any number of containers (except where limited by the residential scavenger
contract); however, whenever the building and zoning official deems necessary to protect the public health, welfare and safety, he may
require the owner of such premises to provide a dumpster(s).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 137/548
3. Maintenance Required:
a. All containers must comply with the standards set forth herein. All containers shall be kept clean, leakproof and disinfected with an
effective antiseptic solution as often as necessary so that same shall remain in a sanitary condition.
b. Compliance with these requirements shall be determined by the village building and zoning official. If the building and zoning official
shall find that the requirements have not been met, he may issue a citation for failure to comply with this chapter, and he may, in
addition, require that the containers will either be repaired or replaced by the occupant and/or the owner of such premises, or the
residential scavenger. Failure to replace the containers within three (3) days after notice shall constitute a violation under this chapter.
4. Placement For Pick Up, Time For Removal: For any premises for which refuse and recycling collection is contained by use of a cart
supplied by the residential scavenger, it shall be the duty of the occupant/owner/customer of such premises to cause such cart to be
placed in the parkway at the curb line, unless other arrangements have been made between such customer and the residential scavenger.
Refuse or recycling carts shall not be set out earlier than six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on the night before collection. All carts shall be removed
from the specified location no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on the day the scavenger has been present for the purpose of
collection and disposal.
5. Placement On Noncollection Days: On days other than the scheduled day for collection, all containers must be screened from view in the
front yard, as provided for in section 10-9-2 of this code.
C. Preparation For Disposal:
1. Garbage: It shall be the duty of every occupant/owner/customer to cause all garbage produced or present on each premises to be
securely wrapped, bagged or packed in a paper or plastic bag constructed of not less than one and one-half (1.5) mill material or a
covered box or carton that will fit into a container. After such preparation, the bag, box or carton shall be deposited into a container which
shall then be closed.
2. Refuse: Refuse must be placed in a container which shall then be closed. Acceptable bulk material or refuse items too large to fit into
residential refuse cart may be placed along side said cart (excluding hazardous materials and any materials banned by law from
collection).
3. Yard Waste:
a. Residential Curbside Collection:
(1) Soft landscape may be deposited into either a biodegradable kraft paper bag, not to exceed thirty three (33) gallons in size and
weighing no more than fifty (50) pounds, or into a can not to exceed thirty four (34) gallons in size or fifty (50) pounds in weight, set
out at the curb with a yard waste sticker attached.
(2) Hard landscape may be placed outside bags and cans if such materials are cut up and securely bound into bundles of no more than
four feet (4') in length and fifty (50) pounds in weight. Each branch shall not exceed two inches (2") in diameter, and each bundle shall
be no more than eighteen inches (18") in total diameter.
(3) Residences serviced by Townhome Association Landscape Contractors shall dispose of yard waste in accordance with their
homeowners' association's rules.
b. Multi-Family And Commercial: All multi-family and commercial premises are required to secure their own yard waste collection service.
The size and number of yard waste dumpsters used and the number of pick ups required shall be commensurate with the amount of
accumulation of yard waste at any one premises.
4. Recyclable Material: Recyclable material should be rinsed clean of food with caps/lids removed before placed into either a recycling cart
or dumpster for collection.
5. Bulk Material And White Goods: Bulk material, white goods and refuse items too large to fit into a refuse cart, may be placed next to a
refuse cart for curbside residential refuse collection. A refrigerator or freezer manufactured prior to 1970 must have the door totally
disconnected and separated therefrom, if manufactured after 1970 the door may be duct taped shut.
D. Disposal By Scavenger: All occupied premises within the village must receive garbage and refuse collection services. Single-family premises
must receive said collection service from the residential scavenger; multi-family and commercial premises must receive said collection
service from a commercial scavenger. No customer/occupant/owner shall use the disposal services of any scavenger not licensed by the
village for the purpose of removal of garbage or refuse. (Ord. 2012-26, 5-29-2012)
5-2-3: PROHIBITIONS REGARDING ACCUMULATION, STORAGE AND DISPOSAL:
The following are prohibited in connection with the accumulation, storage or disposal of garbage or refuse within the village:
A. Failure To Comply With Village Regulations: No customer, occupant, or owner of any premises within the village shall accumulate, store or
dispose of solid or liquid waste in violation of the prohibitions of this section or any other applicable provision of this code.
B. Burning: It shall be unlawful for any person to burn solid or liquid waste within the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 138/548
C. Burying: It shall be unlawful for any person to bury solid or liquid waste anywhere within the village (excluding the composting of yard waste),
or to permit the same to be placed or accumulated in any place or manner other than in a permitted container.
D. Accumulation: It shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate any solid or liquid waste on any premises except in compliance with the
provisions hereof. (Ord. 2012-26, 5-29-2012)
5-2-4: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS:
A. No person shall:
1. Cause or allow the open dumping of any solid or liquid waste on any property within the village.
2. Abandon, dump, or deposit any solid or liquid waste upon public right of way or other public property within the village.
3. Abandon any vehicle in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 of the Illinois vehicle code.
4. Conduct any solid or liquid waste storage, treatment, or disposal without a permit granted by the federal or Illinois environmental
protection agencies or in violation of any conditions imposed by such permit, including periodic reports and full access to adequate
records and the inspection of facilities, as may be necessary to assure compliance with this chapter and with other applicable regulations
and standards.
5. For any detached or attached single-family premises, use a scavenger service other than the village residential scavenger.
6. For any scavenger, who is not the village residential scavenger, to collect or remove garbage, refuse or yard waste from any detached or
attached single-family premises within the village.
7. For any scavenger, who is not licensed by the village, to collect or remove garbage, refuse or yard waste from any premises within the
village. (Ord. 2012-26, 5-29-2012)
5-2-5: REMOVAL OF GARBAGE AND DEBRIS REQUIRED; FAILURE TO COMPLY:
A. It is the duty of the occupant or owner of any property to remove all solid and liquid waste or construction debris from said property or
premises.
B. In the event the occupant or owner of any property or premises refuses or neglects to remove the solid or liquid waste after reasonable notice
from the village, the village may provide for the removal of said solid or liquid waste pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-13, and
collect from such owner the reasonable cost thereof.
C. Within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred, as described in subsection B of this section, the village shall file such a lien in
the office of the county recorder of deeds. (Ord. 2012-26, 5-29-2012)
5-2-6: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided herein, any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to any license
revocation or suspension, and one hundred percent (100%) payment of any unpaid fee, be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
(Ord. 2012-26, 5-29-2012)
ARTICLE A. SCAVENGERS
5-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
COMMERCIAL SCAVENGER: A person, firm or corporation licensed by the village to collect, remove and dispose of garbage and refuse from
each multi-family residential structure of more than two (2) families, and all other premises.
EXCLUSIVE CONTRACT: Written contract for residential scavenger service awarded by the village of Bloomingdale to a single contractor, and
amended from time to time.
RESIDENTIAL SCAVENGER: A person, firm or corporation licensed by the village to collect, remove and dispose of garbage and refuse only
from each and every single-family or duplex residential structure. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982; amd. Ord. 93-55, 11-8-1993)
5-2A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Except as set forth in this chapter, no person, firm or corporation shall remove garbage, refuse or recyclable materials from any premises in the
village, or in any manner dispose of garbage, refuse or recyclables originating within the limits of the village, or contract for or permit himself or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 139/548
itself to be employed or engaged for the removal, transportation or disposal of such garbage, refuse or recyclables without first having secured
from the village a scavenger license. (Ord. 88-43, 9-26-1988)
5-2A-3: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
A. Residential: The village shall issue one scavenger license, which license shall allow for acting as a residential scavenger. The village may
solicit bids for residential scavenger services.
B. Commercial: The village shall issue licenses for commercial scavengers, provided they meet all requirements as set forth by the village. (Ord.
88-43, 9-26-1988)
5-2A-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Application for a scavenger license shall be made to the village clerk upon forms provided. The annual fee as provided in section 4-1-5-1 of this
code shall accompany each application. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982; amd. 2012 Code)
5-2A-5: FINANCIAL AND SERVICE RESPONSIBILITY:
Every applicant must demonstrate that it has adequate and sufficient equipment, personnel, financial responsibility and a licensed and approved
disposal site wherein it may lawfully dispose of all garbage and refuse collected by such licensee within the village. The village administrator
may establish appropriate specifications and procedures for license applications which an applicant must satisfy and fulfill in order to comply
with the provisions hereof. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-6: BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Each scavenger shall provide evidence of workers' compensation insurance coverage in a minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00), pursuant to Illinois law, and shall carry public liability insurance protecting the scavenger and village with limits of not less
than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person, and five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) for any one occurrence, and the scavenger shall
carry property damage insurance protecting the scavenger and the village with limits of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for each occurrence. Such insurance will protect the scavenger and the village from any liability, loss or damage, or any
claims of such liability, loss or damage, resulting, or claimed to have resulted as a result of operations of the scavenger or pursuant to its
operations. Said insurance shall be secured from a responsible company acceptable to the village, and certificates of insurance shall be
furnished to the village by the scavenger.
B. In addition, the scavenger shall agree to and shall hold the village harmless as to any liability or claims of liability arising under or pursuant to
its scavenger operation or contract. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-7: RIGHT TO DENY LICENSE:
The village shall have the right to deny a license to any applicant who fails to meet any applicable requirements of this article, or the application
specifications established by the village. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-8: TERM OF LICENSE; DISPLAY REQUIRED:
Any license shall be in full force and effect and valid for a one year period. The license shall be provided by the village and displayed on each
licensee's motor vehicle used in the village for scavenger purposes. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-9: REMOVAL OF RECYCLABLES FROM APARTMENT BUILDINGS REQUIRED:
A. A commercial scavenger providing service to apartment buildings, as a condition of licensure, shall submit a written plan to the village at the
time when the initial application or renewal for licensure is made, setting forth a recycling plan for the apartments serviced including, but not
limited to:
1. The type of dumpster to be used for collection of recyclable materials.
2. A map showing the dumpster location, which shall be located no more than two hundred feet (200') from the nearest entry or exit into the
apartment building, and a description of the capacity of the dumpster showing a minimum capacity of 0.033 cubic yards per apartment
unit.
B. No commercial scavenger will be permitted to operate within the village offering service to apartment buildings unless and until such time as
that scavenger offers those customers the same recycling opportunities as are offered to other residents in the village by the residential
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 140/548
scavenger operating under exclusive license and contract to the village. (Ord. 93-55, 11-8-1993)
5-2A-10: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
A. Type Of Vehicle: No person, firm or corporation shall transport garbage, refuse or recyclable materials over the streets or other public ways in
the village unless such garbage, refuse or recyclable materials are contained in a leakproof compaction type vehicle, commonly referred to
as a "packer type" refuse body, or a vehicle approved and licensed by the village.
B. Maintenance Required: Such equipment shall be maintained in good condition and repair to prevent nuisance and insect breeding and kept,
when not in use, in a closed building or shed if housed within the village. (Ord. 88-43, 9-26-1988)
5-2A-11: REQUIREMENTS AT COLLECTION SITE:
A. A scavenger shall immediately clean up any garbage, refuse or recyclable materials that it may have caused to spill on private or public
places, and shall perform the function in a neat and workmanlike manner, and shall replace any permanent type garbage containers which
its agents or employees may have damaged. (Ord. 88-43, 9-26-1988; amd. 2012 Code)
B. Containers provided for the recycling program must be stacked and replaced in an orderly fashion near the curb. (Ord. 88-43, 9-26-1988)
5-2A-12: STORAGE AND DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or to store any garbage or refuse in any place within the village limits, without the prior
written permission of the village administrator. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-13: INSPECTIONS:
The village building and zoning official or other personnel designated by the village administrator shall inspect or cause to be inspected, as often
as it is deemed necessary, scavenger refuse vehicles; bulk storage containers of commercial, multi-family, institutional or industrial
establishments; and methods of doing business utilized by each licensee hereunder to determine whether there is compliance with all
applicable provisions of this article. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-14: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
The village shall have the right, after a public hearing pursuant to prior reasonable notice to the scavenger, to revoke or suspend a license if it is
determined that such licensee has violated any of the provisions of this article, or any other applicable provisions of this code or any written
agreement between the village and such scavenger. Any suspension or revocation of a license shall not prevent the imposition of any other
penalty provided in this code. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
5-2A-15: VIOLATIONS PROHIBITED:
No licensee shall dump or otherwise place or dispose of garbage or refuse, construction debris or recyclables in violation of the laws of the state
or the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 82-13, 5-24-1982)
Chapter 3
ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION AND ELIMINATION
5-3-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION AND ELIMINATION
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-2: STATUTE AUTHORITY:
The village promulgates this chapter pursuant to its authority to adopt ordinances pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12,
5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2 and such other authority as applicable to the village, and other applicable authority, all as amended from
time to time. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 141/548
5-3-3: PURPOSES:
A. The purpose of this chapter is to ensure the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of village, and to protect and enhance water
quality in a manner pursuant to and consistent with the federal water pollution control act (33 USC section 1251 et seq.) through the
regulation of nonstormwater discharges to the storm drainage system. This chapter establishes methods for controlling the introduction of
discharges other than those occurring as a direct result of precipitation and/or snowmelt into the municipal separate storm sewer system
(MS4) and the storm drainage system in order to comply with requirements of the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES)
phase II permit process. Other purposes of this chapter include:
1. To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the MS4 and the storm drainage system by nonstormwater discharges; and
2. To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the MS4 and the storm drainage system.
B. The purposes of this chapter are consistent with the county stormwater management plan (the "plan"), which advances the following
objectives:
1. To protect and enhance the quality, quantity, and availability of surface water and groundwater resources.
2. To preserve and enhance existing aquatic and riparian environments and encourage restoration of degraded areas.
3. To promote equitable, acceptable, and legal measures for stormwater management.
C. The purposes of this chapter shall be implemented by its provisions. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-4: RULES AND DEFINITIONS:
A. Interpretation Of Words And Terms: For the purposes of this chapter, the terms and words used herein shall be interpreted as follows:
1. Words used in the present tense include the future tense; and
2. Words used in the singular number include the plural number, and words used in the plural number include the singular number; and
3. The words "shall", "will", and "must" are mandatory, not permissive; and
4. The term "Director" refers to the individual responsible for ordinance administration and enforcement. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
B. Definitions: For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings set forth, except where otherwise
specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have the meanings indicated by common dictionary definition.
BUILDING: A structure that is constructed or erected partially or wholly aboveground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term "building"
includes manufactured homes and includes both the aboveground and the belowground portions of the structure.
CLEAN WATER ACT (CWA): The Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 USC section 1251 et seq.) and any subsequent amendments
thereto.
COMMITTEE: The Village of Bloomingdale Planning, Zoning and Environmental Concerns Committee of the Village Board, or successor
committee.
COMMUNITY: Any municipality or the unincorporated county within DuPage County acting as a unit of local government.
COUNTY: The County of DuPage, Illinois.
DEPARTMENT: The Village of Bloomingdale Engineering Department or successor agency.
DIRECTOR: The Village Engineer or successor position or his or her designee(s).
DRAIN: Piping and appurtenances for conveying a fluid.
FACILITY: Something that is built, installed, or established to serve a particular purpose.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: Any material which may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial hazard to human health, safety,
property, or the environment.
ILLICIT CONNECTION: Either of the following:
1. Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, that allows an illicit discharge to enter the storm drainage system
including, but not limited to, any conveyances that allow any nonstormwater discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and
washwater to enter the storm drainage system and any connections to the storm drainage system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless
of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by the community; or
2. Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drainage system that has not been documented
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 142/548
in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by the community.
ILLICIT DISCHARGE: Any direct or indirect nonstormwater discharge to the storm drainage system, except as exempted in subsection 5-3-
7A3 of this chapter.
INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITIES: Activities subject to an industrial NPDES stormwater permit, as defined in 40 CFR section 122.26 (b)(14).
LINE: A hollow conduit through which fluids are transported between two (2) or more points.
MUNICIPAL SEPARATE STORM SEWER SYSTEM (MS4): A conveyance or system of conveyances (including, but not limited to,
sidewalks, roads with drainage systems, Municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, and storm sewers)
owned or operated by a governmental entity and designed or used for collecting or conveying stormwater, and that is not used for collecting
or conveying sewage.
NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM (NPDES) PERMIT: A permit issued by Illinois environmental protection
agency (IEPA) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual,
group, or general areawide basis.
NONSTORMWATER DISCHARGE: Any discharge to the storm drainage system that is not the direct result of precipitation and/or snowmelt
in the tributary drainage basin.
NOTICE OF INTENT (NOI): Illinois environmental protection agency notice of intent to participate in coverage under the general permit to
discharge stormwater associated with industrial activity.
PARCEL: Contiguous land under single ownership or control.
PERSON: Any individual, association, partnership, public or private corporation, municipality, political subdivision, government agency, or
any other legal entity, including heirs, successors, agents, officers, and assigns of such entity.
pH NEUTRAL: pH value between 6.5 and 9.0 standard units.
PLAN: The DuPage County stormwater management plan, adopted by the DuPage County board in September 1989, as amended from
time to time.
POLLUTANT: Anything that causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to: paints, varnishes, and solvents;
oil and other automotive fluids; nonhazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or
abandoned objects, and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers;
hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, wastewater, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes;
wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind.
PREMISES: Any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land, whether improved or unimproved, including adjacent sidewalks and parking
strips.
RUNOFF: The waters derived from precipitation and/or melting snow within a tributary drainage basin that exceeds the infiltration capacity of
that basin.
SEWAGE: Polluted stormwater, wastewater, or other refuse liquids usually conveyed by sewers.
SEWER: An artificial conduit to carry off sewage and/or surface water (as from rainfall), including sanitation, stormwater, and/or combined
sewers.
SEWERAGE: A system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation, pumping, and treatment of sewage.
STORM DRAINAGE SYSTEM: A facility by which stormwater is collected and/or conveyed, including, but not limited to, any roads with
drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and
humanmade or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures.
STORMWATER: Any surface flow, runoff, and drainage from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation.
STRUCTURE: Anything that is erected or constructed. The term "structure" includes, without limitation: buildings, manufactured homes,
tanks, dams, sewers, constructed channels, outfalls, parking lots, driveways, roads, sidewalks, and concrete patios.
VILLAGE: The Village of Bloomingdale, Illinois, a Municipality with home rule powers pursuant to State Statute.
WASTEWATER: Water that has been used and is not for reuse unless treated by a wastewater treatment facility.
WATERS OF THE UNITED STATES: As defined in the CWA, "waters of the United States", applies only to surface waters, rivers, lakes,
estuaries, coastal waters, and wetlands. Not all surface waters are legally "waters of the United States". Generally, those waters include the
following:
1. All interstate waters;
2. Intrastate waters used in interstate and/or foreign commerce;
3. Tributaries of the above;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 143/548
4. Territorial seas at the cyclical high tide mark; and
5. Wetlands adjacent to all the above. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
5-3-5: APPLICABILITY AND INTERPRETATION:
A. Applicability: This chapter shall apply to all water entering the storm drainage system from any developed or undeveloped lands within the
jurisdiction of the department, unless explicitly exempted by subsection 5-3-7A3 of this chapter, including any amendments or revisions
thereto.
B. Interpretation:
1. The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort,
convenience, prosperity, and general welfare and the environment of the residents of the Village, and to effectuate the purposes of this
chapter and enabling legislation.
2. a. Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this chapter are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions
imposed by any other applicable statute, law, ordinance, regulation, or rule, the provision that is most restrictive or imposes the higher
standards or requirements shall apply.
b. This chapter is not intended to modify or repeal any other ordinance, rule, regulation, or other provision of law. Where any provision of
this chapter imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other ordinance, rule, regulation, or other provision of law,
whichever provision is more restrictive or imposes higher protective standards for human health or the environment shall control.
3. The provisions of this chapter shall be interpreted to be cumulative of, and to impose limitations in addition to, all other ordinances, laws,
codes, and regulations in existence or which may be passed governing any subject matter of this chapter. To the greatest extent possible,
the provisions of this chapter shall be construed to be consistent with, and not in conflict with, the provisions of such other ordinances,
laws, codes, and regulations, and with each other, to the end that all such provisions may be given their fullest application.
4. The standards set forth herein and promulgated pursuant to this chapter are minimum standards; therefore, this chapter does not intend
or imply that compliance by any person will ensure that there will be no contamination, pollution, or unauthorized discharge of pollutants.
(Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-6: ADMINISTRATION OF PROVISIONS:
A. Participating Communities: Participating communities within the County shall promulgate and enforce this chapter in accordance with the
following participation levels. Participation levels shall be established through the adoption of intergovernmental agreements.
1. Duties of a full participant community include:
a. Completion of an intergovernmental agreement for full participation in the Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination Program.
b. Provide the department with a current storm sewer atlas. An updated storm sewer atlas shall be provided to the department annually.
c. Provide assistance to the department in acquiring access to the storm drainage system as mutually deemed necessary.
d. Provide timely prosecution of persons found to be in violation of this chapter when necessary per section 5-3-10 of this chapter.
e. Provide the department with documentation of any enforcement action or prosecution from the previous one year for inclusion in the
IEPA annual facility inspection report.
2. Duties of a partial participant community include:
a. Completion of an intergovernmental agreement for partial participation in the illicit discharge detection and elimination program.
b. Provide the department with a current storm sewer atlas. An updated storm sewer atlas shall be provided to the department annually.
c. Tracing discharges to their source when the department determines that an illicit discharge has been located within the jurisdiction of
the community.
d. Provide timely prosecution of persons found to be in violation of this chapter when necessary per section 5-3-10 of this chapter.
e. Provide the department with documentation of any enforcement action or prosecution from the previous one year for inclusion in the
IEPA annual facility inspection report.
3. Duties of a nonparticipant community include:
a. Responsible for developing and implementing an illicit discharge detection and elimination program to ensure compliance with the IEPA
NPDES regulations within municipal limits on its own behalf.
b. If an intergovernmental agreement is not submitted to the county for partial or full participation, the community will be designated as a
nonparticipant.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 144/548
B. Responsibility For Administration: The department shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. Any powers
granted or duties imposed upon the department may be delegated in writing by the director to persons or entities acting in the beneficial
interest or in the employ of the department as representatives, contractors, designees and/or assigns.
C. Duties Of Director: The duties and functions of the director shall include:
1. Determining policy related to and directing the enforcement of this chapter, as applicable;
2. Supervising the execution of this chapter; and
3. Notifying the communities and the IEPA of any amendments to this chapter.
D. Representative Capacity: In all cases when any action is taken by the director, or his or her duly appointed designee, to enforce the
provisions of this chapter, such action shall be taken in the name of and on behalf of the village, and neither the director nor his or her
designee, in so acting for the village, shall be rendered personally liable. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-7: DISCHARGE PROHIBITIONS AND EXEMPTIONS:
A. Illicit Discharge Prohibitions And Exemptions:
1. No person shall place, drain, or otherwise discharge, cause, or allow others under their control to place, drain, or otherwise discharge into
the storm drainage system or MS4 any pollutants or waters containing any pollutants, other than normal stormwater, unless specifically
exempted in subsection A3 of this section.
2. The following discharges into the MS4 or the storm drainage system shall be prohibited:
a. Discharges that are not a direct result of precipitation and/or snowmelt within the drainage area of the MS4.
b. Discharges from an illicit connection.
3. The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established herein, provided they do not cause an adverse effect on
water quality as determined by the director:
a. Discharges caused by governmental public works and stormwater management units as part of their standard operations in compliance
with all applicable regulations.
b. Discharges required by law or authorized by permit, including any nonstormwater discharge permitted under an NPDES permit, waiver,
or waste discharge order issued to the discharger and administered by the USEPA and/or IEPA.
c. Water line and fire hydrant flushing.
d. Landscape irrigation water.
e. Rising groundwaters.
f. Groundwater infiltration.
g. Pumped groundwater.
h. Discharges from potable water sources.
i. Foundation drains.
j. Air conditioning condensate.
k. Irrigation water (except for wastewater irrigation).
l. Springs.
m. Water from crawl space pumps.
n. Footing drains.
o. Storm sewer cleaning water.
p. Water from any outdoor residential or charitable or nonprofit organization car wash.
q. Routine external building washdown which does not use detergents.
r. Flows from riparian habitats and wetlands.
s. Dechlorinated pH neutral swimming pool discharges.
t. Residual street washwater.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 145/548
u. Discharges or flows from firefighting activities.
v. Dechlorinated water reservoir discharges.
w. Pavement washwaters where spills or leaks of toxic or hazardous materials have not occurred (unless all spilled material has been
removed).
x. Discharges associated with dye testing of water lines, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, private drains or septic systems; however, this
activity shall not take place until the discharger or tester has provided notification to the department at least two (2) full business days
prior to the test date, unless an emergency situation does not allow time for such notification.
y. Other discharges approved by the department as being substantially like any of the discharge types enumerated in this subsection A3.
B. Illicit Connection Prohibitions:
1. The construction, use, maintenance, or continued existence of illicit connections to the storm drainage system or MS4 is prohibited.
2. This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was
permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of connection.
3. A person is considered to be in violation of this chapter if the person connects a line conveying sewage to the storm drainage system or
MS4, or allows such a connection to continue.
4. Connections in violation of this chapter must be disconnected and redirected, if necessary, to an approved wastewater management
system or the sanitary sewer system upon approval of the department and the appropriate sanitary treatment facility.
5. Any drain or conveyance that has not been documented in plans, maps or equivalent, and which may be connected to the storm sewer
system or MS4, shall be located by the owner or occupant of that property upon receipt of written notice of violation from the department
requiring that such locating be completed. Such notice shall specify a reasonable time period within which the location of the drain or
conveyance is to be determined, that the drain or conveyance be identified as a storm sewer, sanitary sewer or other, and that the outfall
location or point of connection to the storm sewer system, MS4, sanitary sewer system, or other discharge point be identified. Results of
these investigations are to be documented and provided to the department. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-8: INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITY DISCHARGES; NOTICE OF INTENT:
A. Any person operating a facility subject to the IEPA's general permit to discharge stormwater associated with industrial activity shall submit a
copy of the notice of intent (NOI) to the county stormwater management division department at the same time the operator submits the
original notice of intent to the IEPA as applicable.
B. The copy of the notice of intent may be delivered to the county stormwater management division either in person or by mailing it to:
Notice Of Intent To Discharge Stormwater
DuPage County Stormwater Management Division
421 North County Farm Road
Wheaton, IL 60187
C. A person commits an offense if the person operates a facility that is discharging stormwater associated with industrial activity without having
submitted a copy of the notice of intent to do so to the county stormwater management division. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-9: COMPLIANCE MONITORING:
A. Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any person owning, leasing or exercising control over a property, or responsible for
emergency response for a property, has information of any known or suspected spill of materials which is resulting or may result in illicit
discharges or pollutants discharging into the MS4 or the storm drainage system, said person shall take all necessary steps to ensure the
discovery, containment, and cleanup of such spill.
B. 1. In the event of such a spill, said person shall immediately notify local emergency dispatch services and act in accordance with Illinois
emergency management agency (IEMA) and IEPA regulations.
2. Said person shall notify the department of the spill in person or by phone, facsimile, or e-mail no later than the next business day.
Notifications in person or by phone shall be confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed to the department within three (3) business
days of the phone notice.
C. If the spill emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment, the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an onsite
written record of the spill and the actions taken to prevent its recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least five (5) years. (Ord.
2009-30, 9-14-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 146/548
D. Proper notice, including containment and cleanup as outlined in subsections A and B of this section shall exempt the notifying parties from
the penalty referenced in subsection 5-3-10F of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code)
E. Failure to provide notification of a release as provided in this section is a violation of this chapter.
F. Notwithstanding the language of subsection D of this section, a party causing a spill that contaminates or harms a storm sewer system shall
not be relieved of liability for damages resulting from such act. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-10: VIOLATIONS, ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
A. Enforcement Official: The director shall have primary responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. The village may enter
into agreements with other governmental units for the purpose of implementing this chapter.
B. Violations: A person violates this chapter when that person:
1. Performs any act expressly prohibited by any provision of this chapter; or
2. Disobeys, neglects, or fails to carry out or comply with any provision of this chapter or of any order or notice issued by the director; or
3. Allows any condition or act that violates any provision of this chapter to continue unabated on property owned, leased, managed, or under
the control of such person; or
4. Directs, orders, permits, or allows a second person to do any act expressly prohibited by any provision of this chapter, or to maintain or
continue unabated any condition or act that violates any provision of this chapter on property owned, leased, managed or under the
control of the first person.
C. Notice To Correct Violations; Director Actions:
1. The director may issue a notice of violation ordering a person to take action to achieve compliance with the provisions of this chapter
and/or to cease and desist from any action conducted in violation of this chapter. Failure to comply with the terms and conditions of a
notice of violation and/or order to cease and desist shall constitute a violation of this chapter.
2. The director shall set forth the form and content of any notices issued under this chapter.
3. The director may issue a warning of violation ordering a person to take action to achieve compliance with the provisions of this chapter. If
a person fails to comply with the terms and conditions of a warning, the director may, thereafter, issue a notice of violation.
4. The director may issue a warning of violation and disburse educational materials outlining appropriate measures to minimize the
discharge of pollutants.
5. If a person fails to comply with an order issued under this subsection, the director may direct the appropriate legal counsel to commence
any legal proceeding authorized by this chapter, under law or equity, necessary to enforce any provision of this chapter and/or to protect
public health and safety. Any legal action brought under this chapter shall be in the name of the village.
D. Emergency Cease And Desist Orders:
1. The department may obtain an emergency order in the event of the following:
a. Any person has violated or continues to violate any provision of this chapter or any order issued hereunder, or that the person's past
violations are likely to recur; and
b. That the person's violation has caused or contributed to an actual or threatened discharge to the MS4 or storm drainage system and an
imminent threat of violation is present.
2. The department may issue the emergency order to the violator directing that the violator:
a. Immediately cease and desist all such violations;
b. Immediately comply with all ordinance requirements; and
c. Take such appropriate preventive action as may be needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation, including
immediately halting operations and/or terminating the discharge.
3. Any person notified of an emergency order under this subsection shall immediately comply and stop or eliminate its endangering
discharge. In the event of a discharger's failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the emergency order, the department may take such
steps as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize harm to the MS4, storm drainage system, or waters of the United States, and/or
endangerment to persons or to the environment, including immediate termination of a facility's water supply, sewer connection, or other
municipal utility services. The department may allow the person to recommence its discharge when it has demonstrated to the satisfaction
of the department that the period of endangerment has passed, unless further termination proceedings are initiated against the discharger
under this chapter. A person that is responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge presenting imminent endangerment shall submit a
detailed written statement, describing the causes of the harmful discharge and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence, to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 147/548
the department within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the emergency order. Issuance of an emergency cease and desist order shall not be a
bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the violator.
E. Nuisance Declared; Abatement Provisions:
1. Declaration Of Nuisance: Any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a threat to
public health and safety and is declared and deemed a public nuisance.
2. Abatement Provisions:
a. Whenever a nuisance shall be found to exist on any premises, the director may order such nuisance to be abated upon determination
that the nuisance constitutes a threat to public health or safety.
b. In the event of an emergency situation, as determined by the director, involving an immediate threat to public health and safety, the
director may direct legal counsel to immediately commence any legal or equitable proceeding necessary to restrain, abate, and/or
remedy said situation. The director may take such action without having to first issue a notice of violation to the person(s) having control
of, or acting as agent for, such premises where the nuisance is located, or waiting for such person(s) to abate or remove such nuisance
as previously ordered by the director.
c. In all other cases, the director may notify, in writing, the person(s) having control of, or acting as agent for, such premises where the
nuisance is located and directing such person(s) to abate or remove such nuisance within such time as is stated on the notice. Upon the
failure or refusal of such person(s) to comply with the notice, the director may direct that appropriate proceedings commence to compel
the abatement or removal of such a nuisance in any manner allowed by law, equity, or this chapter and/or authorizing the department to
act to abate or remove such nuisance. The person(s) having control of such premises, in addition to the other remedies provided by this
chapter, shall be liable to the department for any costs incurred by the department to effect such abatement or removal including
reasonable attorney fees and other costs of enforcement, to be recovered by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-
2009)
F. Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-
2009; amd. 2012 Code)
G. Remedies Not Exclusive: The remedies listed in this chapter are not exclusive of any other remedy available under this chapter or under any
applicable federal, state, or local law and do not supersede or limit any and all other penalties provided by law. The director may seek, at his
discretion, cumulative remedies. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-11: SUSPENSION OF MS4 ACCESS:
A. Any person discharging to the MS4 in violation of this chapter may have his MS4 access terminated if such termination would abate or
reduce an illicit discharge. The department shall notify a violator of the proposed termination of its MS4 access. The violator may petition the
department for a reconsideration and hearing. A person commits an offense if the person reinstates MS4 access to premises terminated
pursuant to this section without the prior approval of the department.
B. In emergency situations, the department may, without prior notice, suspend MS4 discharge access to a person when such suspension is
necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may present imminent and substantial danger to the environment, or
to the health or welfare of persons, or to the MS4, storm drainage system, or waters of the United States. If the violator fails to comply with a
suspension order issued in an emergency, the department may take such steps as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the
MS4, storm drainage system, or waters of the United States, or to minimize danger to public health and safety. The department shall obtain
an emergency court order authorizing such termination. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-12: APPEALS:
A. Every request for an appeal shall be made, in writing, to the director. The director may delegate the hearing of appeals to the committee in
the manner provided in this section.
B. Any person aggrieved by any decision, ruling, or determination by the director, or by any interpretation or application of any provision of this
chapter, may appeal such matter. An appeal of any decision made by the director shall be made within seven (7) days of the decision
contested, except an appeal involving the assessment charge or calculation of any fine or penalty, in which cases, an appeal shall be
brought before said amount becomes thirty (30) days past due.
1. The appeal procedure shall commence when the person aggrieved notifies the director, in writing, of the intent to appeal the decision of
the director. Such notice shall contain a short, clear, statement stating the following:
a. Identifying the decision of the director which such person is appealing and how this chapter has been misread, misinterpreted, or
misapplied in this instance and/or any mistakes of fact the aggrieved believes the director to have relied upon.
b. The name and both a mailing address and a telephone number of the person making the request, which contact information shall be
used for giving notices related to the appeal. The person making the request shall attach all written materials on which he or she intends
to rely upon in support of the request.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 148/548
2. The director may, without conducting a hearing, grant relief sought by the appeal, or may set the matter over for a hearing in the manner
provided in subsection B3 of this section.
3. Upon receipt of such notice of appeal, if relief is not granted by the director in accordance with subsection B2 of this section, the director
shall set a date for a hearing. Such hearing shall take place no fewer than fourteen (14) days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date
that the director receives such notice of appeal, unless the director and party requesting the hearing agree to a different schedule. The
director shall notify the person making the appeal of the date of such hearing.
4. At the hearing, the person making the appeal may appear in person or be represented by counsel, or submit his case in writing. The
decision concerning the appeal shall be in writing, shall be communicated to the person making the appeal, and shall state a finding upon
which the decision is based.
C. The committee shall have the authority to reverse, modify, or affirm any decision, ruling, or determination by the director made pursuant to
this chapter upon appeal. The committee shall not act in a manner that would violate or in any way conflict with any federal or state standard
or requirement. The committee or village board may adopt such additional rules and procedures as it deems appropriate for performing such
matters.
D. The decision of the committee may be appealed to the village board in accord with the village board rules. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
5-3-13: ENFORCEMENT MEASURES AFTER APPEAL:
If the violation has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth in the notice of violation or, in the event of an appeal, within seven
(7) days of the decision of the director or committee upholding the decision of the department, then representatives of the department are
authorized to take any and all measures necessary to abate the violation and/or restore the property. In no case shall an appeal stay or bar the
village from commencing a legal action seeking emergency relief. (Ord. 2009-30, 9-14-2009)
Chapter 4
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS DISCHARGE
5-4-1: INTENT:
It is the intent of this chapter:
A. To establish the legal authority of the village to enable the establishment of policies and procedures to inspect, perform surveillance, monitor,
perform emergency response, containment and remediation; to declare as a public nuisance, and therefore unlawful and subject to
prosecution, any wilful or accidental acts to cause discharges, deposits, spills, placements, and/or dumps of hazardous materials either over,
under, or onto public and private properties, or any location where not intended, which endangers or may endanger the public health, safety
and welfare, and the environment in the village; and
B. To establish a means to impose fines and penalties and recoup village expenses incurred to investigate, inspect, perform surveillance,
monitor, declare a public nuisance, respond, contain and remediate any damages caused by wilful or accidental acts, to cause deposits,
spills, placements, dumps, and discharges of hazardous materials either over, under, or onto any premises, or any location where not
intended or permitted. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
5-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall mean:
DISCHARGE: Any direct or indirect, wilful or accidental, spill, placement, deposit, dump, and/or discharge of a hazardous material over, under,
or onto a premises.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: Any material, or combination of materials, in any state of matter including, but not limited to, any substance, waste,
or combination thereof, which, because of its location, quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or
significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to the public health, safety, welfare, and/or the environment when improperly
treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed including, but not limited to, materials or substances that are caustic,
flammable, poisonous, carcinogenic or acidic.
PERSON: Any individual, owner, lessee, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation, business, trust, discharger, or other entity
recognized by law and acting as the owner, owner's agent, operator, assign, successor, heir or in any other capacity that results in any wilful or
accidental acts to cause discharges of hazardous materials.
PREMISES: Any public or private building, facility, lot, parcel of land, property, or portion of land, whether improved or unimproved, developed or
undeveloped, including public rights of way and public or private easements, roads, streets, driveways, sidewalks, parking strips and lots.
VILLAGE: The village of Bloomingdale. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 149/548
5-4-3: APPLICABILITY AND INTERPRETATION:
A. Applicability: This chapter shall apply to any discharges of hazardous materials as defined in section 5-4-2 of this chapter.
B. Minimum Requirements: The provisions set forth herein are considered minimum provisions. Therefore, this chapter neither intends nor
implies that compliance with these minimum provisions will ensure that there will be no prosecution against any person causing wilful or
accidental contamination, pollution, or unauthorized discharges of hazardous materials pursuant to regulations promulgated by other
agencies such as USEPA and IEPA.
C. Severability:
1. The provisions, clauses, sentences and paragraphs of this chapter are hereby declared to be severable in accordance with the following
rules:
a. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this chapter as invalid, then such
judgment shall not affect any other provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this chapter.
b. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge invalid the application of any provision of this chapter to a particular person or
premises, such judgment shall not affect the application of said provision to any other person or premises.
2. All such unaffected provisions, clauses, sentences, or paragraphs of this chapter shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-
2009)
5-4-4: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
The Department of Public Works, managed by the Director of Public Works and Village Engineer, shall administer, implement, and enforce the
provisions of this chapter. Any powers granted or duties imposed pursuant to this chapter may be delegated in writing by the Director of Public
Works and Village Engineer to persons in the employ of the Village, as representatives, contractors, designees, assigns and/or entities acting in
the beneficial interest of the Village. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
5-4-5: DISCHARGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge hazardous material(s) on any premises within the Village. This prohibition shall not apply to any
person permitted under a USEPA, IEPA, or NPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the person and administered under the
authority of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) or Illinois Environmental Protection Agency (IEPA); provided, that the
person is in full compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and any other applicable laws and regulations; and provided,
that written approval or permit has been granted. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
5-4-6: NUISANCE DECLARED:
In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions
of this chapter is a threat to the public health, safety, welfare and/or the environment and is hereby declared and deemed a nuisance, and may
be summarily abated or restored at the violator's expense, and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin, or otherwise compel the cessation of such
nuisance may be taken. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
5-4-7: ACCESS TO PREMISES:
This section applies to any persons or premises reasonably suspected of violating the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009;
amd. 2012 Code)
A. After thirty (30) days' notice in nonemergency cases, and without prior notice in the case of an emergency, the Director of Public Works or
Village Engineer shall be permitted reasonable access, as often as may be reasonably necessary, to enter into, onto and upon a premises to
cause inspections to determine compliance and/or conduct emergency response, containment and/or remediation.
B. Except in conditions of emergency, if the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer has been refused access to any part of a premises,
and the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of any
provision of this chapter, or that there is a need to inspect, monitor, sample the premises to verify compliance with the provisions of this
chapter, or any order issued hereunder, or to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and the environment, then the Director of Public
Works or Village Engineer may seek issuance of a search warrant from a court of competent jurisdiction.
C. Unreasonable delays in allowing the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer access to a premises reasonably suspected of violating
provisions of this chapter is considered to be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-
2017)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 150/548
5-4-8: NOTIFICATION OF DISCHARGE:
Notwithstanding other requirements of law, any person responsible for a discharge of hazardous material(s) from, over, under, or onto any
premises shall immediately contact emergency response agencies of said occurrence via emergency dispatch services and the Director of
Public Works or Village Engineer, and shall immediately take all necessary steps to ensure the containment and remediation of such
discharge(s) of hazardous material(s). Failure to provide said notice shall constitute a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd.
2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
5-4-9: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
A. Whenever the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer discovers, finds, determines or reasonably suspects that a person has violated a
provision of this chapter, then the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer may, by written notice of violation to the responsible person or
persons and by posting a copy of said notice of violation on the subject premises, order compliance. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012
Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
B. Such notice of violation ordering compliance may require without limitation:
1. The suspension of activities causing the discharge(s); and
2. The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting; and
3. The elimination of said discharge(s); and
4. That said discharge(s) shall cease and desist; and
5. The abatement or remediation of contamination or hazards and the restoration of any affected premises; and
6. The payment of fines, fees, and costs of abatement and remediation; and
7. Other reasonable actions, orders, provisions or requirements intended to protect the public health, safety, welfare, and the environment.
(Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
C. Except in the case of emergency permitting immediate access, if the notice of violation orders monitoring, sampling, abatement, containment
remediation and/or restoration of the affected premises, then said notice of violation shall set forth a deadline, not less than fifteen (15)
calendar days after the date of the notice, when such monitoring sampling, abatement, remediation, and/or restoration shall be completed.
Said notice shall further advise that, should the violator fail to restrain or cease actions causing the violation, or fail to monitor, sample,
abate, remediate or restore the premises within the established deadline, then the required order conditions may be completed by the
Director of Public Works or Village Engineer, and the expenses thereof shall be charged to the person or persons violating this chapter. (Ord.
2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
D. As necessary and required, the Village may institute appropriate action or proceedings in the Circuit Court of DuPage County, or other
applicable court, to cause the violator to restrain, monitor, sample, abate, restore, remediate and/or reimburse the Village for such violation.
(Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
5-4-10: SUSPENSION OF ACTIVITIES:
A. Emergency Situations:
1. In cases of imminent and substantial emergency, as declared by the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer, or other sworn
Municipal official, the Village may, without prior notice, suspend or cause the suspension of activities by a person causing a discharge
when such suspension is necessary to stop, prevent or minimize an actual or threatened discharge which presents, or may present, an
imminent and substantial danger to the public health, safety and welfare, and/or the environment. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012
Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
2. If the person(s) notified of said declaration of any emergency and of said violation of this chapter fails to comply with the suspension order
issued in an emergency, then the Village may take such steps as deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety, welfare and/or the
environment.
B. Nonemergency Situations:
1. Any person suspected, observed, discovered or detected of a discharge in violation of this chapter may have said activity suspended or
terminated if doing so is deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety, welfare and/or the environment. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
2. The Director of Public Works or Village Engineer will serve said person, in writing, with a notice of violation indicating the suspected,
observed, discovered or detected discharge of hazardous material(s) in violation of this chapter and describing the necessary action(s) to
achieve compliance. The person receiving a notice of violation shall suspend activities outlined in said notice until compliance is achieved.
3. Any person shall be considered violating the provisions of this chapter and subject to prosecution if said person resumes a discharge
previously suspended or terminated pursuant to this section without the prior approval of the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 151/548
(Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
5-4-11: ABATEMENT COSTS:
A. Any person found violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the Village by reason of such violation for any direct
and indirect costs including, but not limited to, administrative, legal and court costs, costs incurred to cause restraint, monitoring, sampling,
abatement, restoration, containment, remediation, and/or other reasonable actions to protect the public health, safety, welfare and/or the
environment. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
B. After the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer compiles the total costs, the person(s) responsible for said violation will be notified of
and invoiced for said total costs incurred by the Village. Said costs shall become the liability of the person(s) found responsible for the
violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
C. If the amount due is not paid within thirty (30) calendar days pursuant to the terms and conditions of the invoice submitted by the Village,
then the charges shall become a lawful encumbrance against the person and/or premises and shall constitute a lien against the person
and/or the premises for the full amount. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
D. At his sole discretion, the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer may permit the responsible person(s) to satisfy the liability, in equal
installments, for a duration determined by the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer, but in no case to exceed ten (10) years. The
liability shall accrue interest at an annual percentage rate to be determined by the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer, upon advice
of the Finance Director-Treasurer, but in no case less than a five percent (5%) annual percentage rate. Said interest shall be assessed on
the balance beginning on the thirtieth day following the date of first invoice. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-
13-2017)
5-4-12: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF; LEGAL AND EQUITABLE RELIEF:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any provision of this chapter. A person who has violated or
continues to violate the provisions of this chapter is hereby determined to be subjecting, or has subjected, imminent or substantial danger to
the public health, safety, welfare and/or the environment.
B. In such cases, the Village shall have authority to cause to be instituted a civil action or petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction
restraining the person from activities which would create further violations and/or compel the person to perform abatement, remediation or
restoration of the violation. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
C. In the enforcement of this chapter, the Director of Public Works or Village Engineer may have authority to institute or cause to be instituted, in
the name of the Village, any and all required actions, legal and equitable, including appeals. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009; amd. 2012 Code;
Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
5-4-13: PENALTIES:
Any person that has violated or continues to violate this chapter shall be subject to civil or criminal prosecution and imprisonment to the fullest
extent permitted by the law, and shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code. The Village may recover all attorney fees, court
costs, administrative fees and expenses, and other associated expenses pursuant to provisions outlined in this chapter. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-
2009; amd. 2012 Code)
5-4-14: REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE:
The remedies listed in this chapter are not exclusive of any other remedies available under any applicable Federal, State or local law, and it is
within the discretion of the Village to seek cumulative remedies. (Ord. 2009-31, 9-14-2009)
Chapter 5
NOISE CONTROL1
5-5-1: NOISE PROHIBITED GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary, or unusual noise or any noise
which either annoys, disturbs, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others within the limits of the village. (Ord. 72-29, 7-
12-1972; amd. 2012 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 152/548
5-5-2: SPECIFIC ACTS PROHIBITED:
The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noises in violation of this chapter, but said enumeration
shall not be deemed to be exclusive:
A. Vehicle Noises:
1. The sounding of any horn or signaling device of any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place of the village,
except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the
sounding of any such device unnecessarily or for an unreasonable period of time.
2. The use of any signaling device, except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle, or other device operated by
engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic for any reason is held up.
3. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary
grating, grinding, rattling, or other such noise.
B. Exhaust: The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat, or other
motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom.
C. Steam Whistle: The blowing of any locomotive steam whistle or steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the
time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper village authorities.
D. Transportation Of Metal Rails, Pillars And Columns: The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material over and
along streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to
disturb the peace and quiet of such streets or other public places.
E. Radios And Phonographs: The using or operating, or the permitting to be played, used or operated, of any radio, receiving set, musical
instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet
and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or
persons who are in the room, vehicle, or chamber in which the machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The
operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) A.M. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of fifty feet (50') from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is
located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this subsection.
F. Drums: The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance, show, or sale by
creation of noise.
G. Loudspeakers And Amplifiers: Playing, using or operating, or permitting to be played, used, or operated, any radio, receiving set, musical
instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast
upon the public street for the use and purposes of commercial advertising or for attracting the attention of the public to any building or
structure.
H. Yelling And Shouting: Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of eleven o'clock
(11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., or at any time or place so as to annoy or destroy the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any
office or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence or of any persons in the vicinity.
I. Hawkers And Peddlers: The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood.
(Ord. 72-29, 7-12-1972)
J. Animals: The keeping of any animal which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in
the vicinity. (Ord. 72-29, 7-12-1972; amd. 2012 Code)
K. Loading, Unloading, Opening Boxes: The creating of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the
opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers.
L. Construction Or Repair Of Buildings: The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building other than between
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M., except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and
safety, and then only with a permit from the building and zoning official, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3)
days or less while the emergency continues, and which permit may be renewed for a period of three (3) days or less while the emergency
continues.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 153/548
M. Pile Drivers And Hammers: The operation of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other
appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
N. Blowers: The operation of any noise creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise
due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a
muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. (Ord. 72-29, 7-12-1972)
O. Near Schools, Courts, Places Of Worship And Hospitals And Care Centers: The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to
any school, institution of learning, place of worship, or court of law while the same is in use, or adjacent to any hospital or care center, which
unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital or care center,
provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or care center, or court of law street.
(Ord. 72-29, 7-12-1972; amd. 2012 Code)
5-5-3: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-4-1
of this code for each offense. (Ord. 72-29, 7-12-1972; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE A. SOUND TRUCKS
5-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
SOUND AMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT: Any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music or other sound. The term "sound
amplifying equipment" shall not be construed as including standard automobile radios when used and heard only by occupants of the vehicle in
which installed or warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles or horns or other warning devices on other vehicles used only for traffic
safety purposes.
SOUND TRUCK: Any vehicle, self-propelled or otherwise, having mounted thereon or attached thereto any sound amplifying equipment. (Ord.
72-29, 7-12-1972)
5-5A-2: NONCOMMERCIAL SOUND TRUCKS:
A. Registration Statement:
1. No person shall use, or cause to be used, a sound truck with its sound amplifying equipment in operation for noncommercial purposes in
the village before filing a registration statement with the village clerk in writing. This registration statement shall be filed in duplicate and
shall state the following:
a. Name and home address of the applicant.
b. Address of place of business of applicant.
c. License number and motor number of the sound truck to be used by the applicant.
d. Name and address of the person who owns the truck.
e. Name and address of the person having direct charge of the sound truck.
f. Names and addresses of all persons who will use or operate the sound truck.
g. The purpose for which the sound truck will be used.
h. A general statement as to the section or sections of the village in which the sound truck will be used.
i. The proposed hours of operation of the sound truck.
j. The number of days of proposed operation of the sound truck.
k. A general description of the sound amplifying equipment which is to be used.
l. The maximum sound producing power of the sound amplifying equipment to be used in or on the sound truck.
(1) The wattage to be used.
(2) The volume in decibels of the sound which will be produced.
(3) The approximate maximum distance for which sound will be thrown from the sound truck.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=943 154/548
2. The village clerk shall return to each applicant for registration hereunder one copy of said registration statement, duly certified by the
village clerk, as a correct copy of said application. Said certified copy of the application shall be in the possession of any person operating
the sound truck at all times while the sound truck is in operation, and said copy shall be promptly displayed to any police officer of the
village upon request.
B. Regulations: Noncommercial use of sound trucks in the village with sound amplifying equipment in operation shall be subject to the following
regulations:
1. The only sounds permitted shall be music or human speech.
2. Operations shall be permitted only between the hours of eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) A.M. and one thirty o'clock (1:30) P.M. and between
the hours of four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. and six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M. Provided, however, that no operations shall be authorized or
